{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox building |name = 550 Madison Avenue |image = Sony Building by David Shankbone crop.jpg |image_size = 225px |caption = Sony Tower in 2007 |coordinates = {{coord|40|45|41|N|73|58|24|W|region:US-NY_source:dewiki|display=inline,title}} |address = 550 Madison Avenue
[[New York City]], U.S. |start_date = 1980{{Cite web|url=https://skyscrapercenter.com/building/550-madison-avenue/1783|title=The Skyscraper Center|access-date=2017-03-14}} |completion_date = 1984 |opening = |building_type = [[Offices]] |architectural_style= [[Postmodern architecture|Postmodern]] |antenna_spire = |roof = {{Convert|647|ft|m|0|abbr=on}} |top_floor = |floor_count = 37 |elevator_count = |floor_area = |architect = [[Philip Johnson]] and [[John Burgee]] |structural_engineer= Leslie E. Robertson Associates
[[Cosentini Associates]] |main_contractor = |developer = |owner = The [[Olayan Group]] (Olayan America){{Cite web|url=http://ny.curbed.com/2016/6/9/11893486/sony-building-chetrit-group-olayan-america-sale|title=Sony Building's $1.4b sale hits public record, making it official|last=Plitt|first=Amy|date=2016-06-09|website=Curbed NY|access-date=2016-06-10}} |cost = |current_tenants = |landlord = |management = |references = }} '''550 Madison Avenue''' (formerly known as the '''Sony Tower''' or '''Sony Plaza''' and before that the '''AT&T Building'''), is an iconic [[postmodern architecture|postmodern]] {{Convert|647|ft|m|0|adj=mid|-tall|abbr=off|sp=us}}, 37-story [[highrise]] [[skyscraper]] located at 550 [[Madison Avenue]] in [[Manhattan]].{{cite web|title=Sony Tower|url=http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=sonytower-newyorkcity-ny-usa|publisher=Emporis.com|accessdate=July 12, 2008}} Designed by [[Philip Johnson]], it was formerly the headquarters of [[Sony Corporation of America]]. The tower was purchased by the [[Olayan Group]] and Chelsfield for $1.4 billion in 2016. ==History== ===Design=== The building was designed by [[architect]] [[Philip Johnson]] and partner [[John Burgee]] and was completed in 1984. It is close – in concept – to the 1982 [[Humana Building]] by [[Michael Graves]]. It became immediately controversial for its ornamental top (sometimes mocked as "[[Thomas Chippendale|Chippendale]]",{{cite web|title=Chippendale Building (SONY building) |url= http://www.barrypopik.com/index.php/new_york_city/entry/chippendale_building_sony_building |publisher=Barry Popik|accessdate=September 2, 2008}} after the [[pediment|open pediments]] characteristic of the famous English designer's bookcases and other cabinetry), but enjoyed for its spectacular arched entrance way, measuring about seven stories in height. With these ornamental additions, the building challenged [[modernist architecture|architectural modernism]]'s demand for stark functionalism and purely efficient design. The effect the building had on the public at large has been described as legitimizing the [[postmodern architecture]] movement on the world stage. In July 2018 it was designated a New York City landmark by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.{{Cite web|url=https://archpaper.com/2018/07/johnson-burgees-att-building-new-york-city-landmark/|title=The AT&T Building is now a New York City landmark - Archpaper.com|website=archpaper.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-03}} ===AT&T Building=== In October 1978, AT&T was granted permission to add {{convert|81928|sqft|m2|abbr=off|sp=us}}, the equivalent of some four floors of space on its proposed building, in exchange for agreeing to provide open public space and a three-story communications museum. The firm was granted an additional {{convert|43000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}}, about two floor's worth, as a bonus for creating a {{convert|14000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} covered arcade along Madison Avenue that would include seating and retail kiosks.Gottlieb, Martin. [https://select.nytimes.com/search/restricted/article?res=F50E12F83C5F0C768EDDAC0894DC484D81 "A.T.&T. PLANNING CHANGE IN PACT WITH CITY FOR MUSEUM AT TOWER"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', May 25, 1984. Retrieved October 12, 2008. [[File:Sony Building by Matthew Bisanz.jpg|left|thumb|Main entrance]] In 1982, with the [[Bell System divestiture]] set to take effect on January 1, 1984, AT&T decided to seek a tenant to lease {{convert|300000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of space on the 7th through 25th floors, nearly half the space in the building, and was seeking rents of as much as $60 per square foot. The company had expected to relocate as many as 1,500 employees, most who had been located at the company's old headquarters at 195 Broadway, but the impending divestiture meant it would only be moving 600 employees into 550 Madison, with others being moved to another facility in [[Basking Ridge, New Jersey]].Henry, Diane. [https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/29/business/real-estate-at-t-in-role-of-landlord.html "Real Estate; A.T.& T. In Role of Landlord"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', September 29, 1982. Retrieved October 11, 2008. ''[[Spirit of Communication]]'', a {{convert|20000|lb|kg|adj=on|abbr=off}} bronze statue that had stood for 64 years at the top of AT&T's previous headquarters building at [[195 Broadway|195]] [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]], was disassembled and relocated to the lobby of 550 Madison in 1983. The {{convert|22|ft|m|abbr=on}} figure, modeled in 1916 by American sculptor [[Evelyn Beatrice Longman]], is holding bolts of electricity clutched in one arm reaching towards the sky and has coils of cable wound around the statue's torso.Teltsch, Kathleen. [https://select.nytimes.com/search/restricted/article?res=F20C16FD385F0C728FDDA10894D9484D81 "LANDMARK STATUE BEING RESTORED"], August 31, 1981. Retrieved October 11, 2008. After AT&T moved out of the building, the statue was relocated to a spot outside of its Basking Ridge operational headquarters in 1992.Dewan, Shaila. [https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/20/nyregion/at-t-statue-to-remain-suburban.html "AT&T Statue to Remain Suburban"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', April 20, 2000. Retrieved October 12, 2000. In 2009, the statue was relocated to AT&T's current corporate headquarters in Dallas. In 1984, the company indicated that it would not build the museum that it had originally committed to build in exchange for bonus zoning. The change of heart came as part of plans following the court-ordered divestiture of the [[Regional Bell Operating Companies]] and the reduced presence it expected to have at the building. In the face of firm opposition from the city, AT&T acquiesced to construction of a three-story exhibition space in an annex located adjoining the pedestrian walkway behind the building.Gottlieb, Martin. [https://select.nytimes.com/search/restricted/article?res=FB0B1FF9385D0C728DDDAE0894DC484D81 "A.T.&.T.IN A REVERSAL, TO OPEN EXHIBITION SPACE"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', July 11, 1984. Retrieved October 12, 2008. [[File:Sony bldg Manhattan west jeh.JPG|thumb|Western or "behind" side]] AT&T had been granted a tax break of $42 million, under the condition that the company would keep its headquarters at 550 Madison Avenue and not rent out the space to other tenants. Having decreased in size substantially, AT&T signed a 20-year lease agreement on 550 Madison with Sony and relocated its headquarters to [[32 Sixth Avenue]], between Walker and Lispenard Streets. Sony was granted an option to purchase the building. AT&T returned $14.5 million to New York City to compensate it for tax abatements made as part of a 1987 renegotiation.Dunlap, David W. [https://www.nytimes.com/1992/05/01/nyregion/plan-reduces-public-areas-for-a-tower.html "Plan Reduces Public Areas For a Tower"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', May 1, 1992. Retrieved October 11, 2008. ===Sony Building=== [[File:550 Madison Avenue July2015.JPG|thumb|Sony Building in 2015]] In 1992, Sony submitted plans that required approval by the [[New York City Planning Commission]], in which it would take some of the open space in the building's [[atrium (architecture)|atrium]] that had been used to obtain approval for additional floors on top of the building, and convert those areas into retail space. In exchange, the company would expand the glass-enclosed pedestrian walkway with the addition of planters and public seating. Sony expected that the proposed conversion of the {{convert|8727|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of public space could be converted into stores that could be leased at rates that ''[[The New York Times]]'' estimated could approach $200 per square foot. The company noted that the space was underutilized as a public amenity because it was "dark, windy and noisy" and that its conversion to commercial space would provide "retail continuity" with the remainder of Madison Avenue. By 1996, Sony had consolidated most of the operations for its [[Sony Music Entertainment]] division at 550 Madison Avenue, for which ''[[The New York Times]]'' noted that "such high-profile and elaborate space is appropriate and necessary." That same year, Sony acquired additional space across the street at 555 Madison Avenue, a {{convert|445000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} building built in the 1960s that underwent renovations of its lobby, windows, bathrooms and other common spaces in conjunction with Sony's lease. Sony signed leases through 2013 on an additional {{convert|90000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} on the sixth through ninth floors of the building, on top of an initial rental of {{convert|90000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of space on the second through fifth floors of the building that it had made in 1995. Rents on the floors had averaged about $34 per square foot at the time. Sony connected the two buildings using fiber optic cables that were run under Madison Avenue and installed microwave communications equipment on the top of the 555 building. Sony made these moves, which included early termination of leases on space in the surrounding area at 711 Fifth Avenue on the 43rd floor at [[9 West 57th Street]], as part of an effort to lower occupancy costs by bringing its businesses closer together.Rothstein, Mervyn. [https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/03/business/real-estate-sony-makes-number-moves-manhattan-put-more-its-businesses-under-one.html "Real Estate; Sony makes a number of moves in Manhattan to put more of its businesses under one roof."], ''[[The New York Times]]'', April 3, 1996. Retrieved October 11, 2008. A cash-strapped AT&T sold the building to Sony in 2002 for $236 million, or $315 per square foot.Magpily, Gerald. [http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-55779_ITM "DealEstate — April 11, 2002"], ''[[The Deal (magazine)|Daily Deal]]'', April 11, 2002. Retrieved October 12, 2008. The building incorporated the Sony Wonder Technology Lab, a multimedia hands-on tour through the world of media, located in a four-story annex accessible through a glass-roofed atrium that connects 55th and 56th Streets in mid-block.Leimbach, Dulcie. [https://www.nytimes.com/1994/06/24/arts/for-children.html "For Children"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', June 24, 1994. Retrieved October 11, 2008. It was open on Tuesdays through Saturdays, and Sony described the free exhibits as a "technology and entertainment museum for all ages". During 2008, the museum's third and fourth floors underwent renovations that were completed in fall 2008. Sony Wonder replaced Infoquest Center, a permanent telecommunications exhibition that had been built by AT&T. Sony permanently closed the lab on January 29, 2016.{{Cite web|url=https://www.mommynearest.com/edition/nyc/article/sony-wonder-technology-lab-to-close-on-january-29|title=Sony Wonder Technology Lab to Close Its Doors January 29|last=|first=|date=2016-01-14|website=Mommy Nearest|access-date=2017-10-31}} On February 27, 2010, an accumulation of ice from the [[February 25–27, 2010 North American blizzard]] broke loose from an upper floor, breaking the glass ceiling of the atrium and injuring at least 15 inside who were attending a [[Purim]] celebration.{{cite news|author =AP |url= https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5g1ibPLmiXR4R1WxvRWLi9tp-vYRwD9E5GIT00 |title=Witness: Glass 'everywhere' in NYC atrium collapse – Associated Press – March 1, 2010 |publisher=Google.com |date=February 28, 2010 |accessdate=March 15, 2010}}[https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5g1ibPLmiXR4R1WxvRWLi9tp-vYRwD9E5GIT00 "AP News; February 28, 2010"]. Retrieved February 28, 2010. In December 2012, bidding started on the building{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/12/10/usaproperty-sony-idUSL1E8NA76O20121210|title=First-round bids for NYC's Sony Tower due on Monday|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=April 23, 2013|date=December 10, 2012}} and in January 2013 Sony announced plans to sell the building to the Chetrit Group for $1.1 billion – $685 million more than it had paid for it. Sony [[leaseback|leased back]] its offices there through 2016,{{cite news| url=http://www.sony.com/en_us/SCA/company-news/press-releases/sony-corporation-of-america/2013/sony-corporation-of-america-announces-sale-of-550-.html?icid=pr-newswire-feed |title=Sony Corporation of America Announces Sale of 550 Madison Avenue Building |date=January 17, 2013 | publisher=[[Sony Corporation of America]] | accessdate=2015-08-24| quote=The sale price is $1.1 billion, and it is expected that the transaction will close in March 2013. SCA and other Sony businesses ... will remain in the building for up to three years under a leaseback arrangement with the purchaser..}} when it moved its headquarters south to 11 Madison Avenue.{{Cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/6897150/sony-completes-move-of-its-nyc-headquarters|title=Sony Completes Move of Its NYC Headquarters|website=Billboard|access-date=2016-06-10}} ===Redevelopment=== The Chetrit Group planned to redevelop the building as a combination of condominiums and a hotel.{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/metropolis/2014/06/09/portion-of-sony-building-to-become-high-end-condos/|title=Portion of Sony Building to Become High-End Condos|last=Brown|first=Eliot|website=WSJ|access-date=2016-06-10}} Chetrit abandoned this plan and sold the building to Olayan and Chelsfield in 2016, relinquishing the "Sony Tower" name.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/30/nyregion/plan-to-turn-sony-building-into-high-end-apartments-is-abandoned.html|title=Plan to Turn Sony Building Into Luxury Apartments Is Abandoned|last=Bagli|first=Charles V.|date=2016-04-29|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-06-10}} Olayan and Chelsfield have announced plans to rebrand the building and reconfigure the existing space. Other than a ground floor restaurant, the building is currently empty.{{Cite web|url=http://therealdeal.com/2016/06/02/olayan-closes-on-sony-building-gets-570m-bridge-loan/|title=Olayan closes on Sony Building buy, gets $570M bridge loan|last=Mashayekhi|first=Rey|last2=|date=2016-06-02|website=The Real Deal New York|access-date=2016-06-10|last3=|first3=|last4=|first4=|last5=|first5=}} In late October 2017, the [[Olayan Group]] announced its plans for a large renovation of the building, with the architectural firm [[Snøhetta (company)|Snøhetta]] to design the changes. The firm plans a glass curtain wall over the street front and plans to replace a glass arcade and annex building with an outdoor garden.{{Cite news|url=http://www.metropolismag.com/architecture/snohetta-att-building-remodel/|title=Snohetta Will Remodel Philip Johnson's AT&T Building|date=2017-10-30|work=Metropolis|access-date=2018-08-03|language=en-US}} Several architecture critics, architects, artists, and others voiced their opposition to the plans.{{Cite web|url=https://archpaper.com/2017/10/protest-planned-controversy-erupts-att-building/|title=Protest planned as controversy erupts over AT&T Building - Archpaper.com|website=archpaper.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-03}} A November protest and the petition, organized by [https://vimeo.com/241413433 Starship Chicago] and [https://vimeo.com/77616076 The Absent Column] filmmaker Nathan Eddy, drew widespread [https://www.dezeen.com/2017/11/03/architects-protest-snohetta-plans-att-building-philip-johnson-new-york/ media coverage].{{Cite news|url=https://www.dezeen.com/2017/11/03/architects-protest-snohetta-plans-att-building-philip-johnson-new-york/|title=Architects protest AT&T Building plans with "Hands off my Johnson" placards|date=2017-11-03|work=Dezeen|access-date=2018-08-03|language=en-US}} A week later, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission announced it would vote to decide whether or not to calendar the building for landmark status consideration.{{Cite news|url=https://www.architecturaldigest.com/story/snohetta-proposed-renovation-philip-johnsons-atandt-building-landmark-status|title=After Protests Over Snøhetta's Proposed Renovation, Philip Johnson’s AT&T Building May Get Landmark Status {{!}} Architectural Digest|work=Architectural Digest|access-date=2018-08-03|language=en}} On November 27, the LPC [https://www.wsj.com/articles/towering-landmark-battle-looms-over-philip-johnson-building-1511912467 voted unanimously] to put the building on its calendar, though a specific date has not been set.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/towering-landmark-battle-looms-over-philip-johnson-building-1511912467|title=Towering Landmark Battle Looms Over Philip Johnson Building|last=Morris|first=Keiko|date=2017-11-28|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-08-03|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}} Despite efforts to preserve the tower's architecture and significant interiors, demolition of the building's original ground floor lobby began in January 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dezeen.com/2018/01/22/opinion-philip-johnson-att-building-550-madison-preservation-christy-maclear/|title=Opinion: "550 Madison is worthy of the most careful preservation"|date=2018-01-22|work=Dezeen|access-date=2018-01-24|language=en-US}} The protests and ensuing debate landed the building on the list of the [https://archpaper.com/2017/12/12-best-architecture-controversies-year-2017/ most controversial] architecture stories of 2017.{{Cite web|url=https://archpaper.com/2017/12/12-best-architecture-controversies-year-2017/|title=Outrageous! The 12 best architecture controversies of 2017 - Archpaper.com|website=archpaper.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-03}} On July 31, 2018, the LPC voted unanimously to designate the entire exterior of the building a New York City landmark,http://s-media.nyc.gov/agencies/lpc/lp/2600.pdf less than a year after the protests for its protection began. {{Cite news|url=https://www.dezeen.com/2018/08/01/att-building-philip-johnson-landmark-status-snohetta-plans-scrapped/|title=Snøhetta plans nixed as Philip Johnson's AT&T Building receives landmark status|last=|first=|date=2018-08-01|work=Dezeen|access-date=2018-08-03|language=en-US}} Eddy described the landmarking as "an astonishing and marvelous victory". ==In other media== The Sony Tower appears in the original Spider-Man game ''[[Spider-Man (2000 video game)]]'' in the first level of the game. as well as in the 2002 video game, ''[[Spider-Man (2002 video game)|Spider-Man: The Movie]],'' in the level "Oscorp's Gambit". This is probably because Sony owns the rights to [[Spider-Man]]. The tower later appears in the game's sequel, ''[[Spider-Man 2 (video game)|Spider-Man 2]],'' as a building in the free-roaming Manhattan map. It also appears in ''[[Marvel's Spider-Man (video game)|Marvel's Spider-Man (2018 video game)]] in the free roam. It is also featured in the movie "Wall Street", both as general office space (James Spader) and the CEO office (Michael Douglas as Gordon Gekko). ==See also== {{Portal|Architecture|New York City}} *[[List of tallest buildings in New York City]] *[[AT&T Corporate Center]] *[[Sony Building (Tokyo)]] http://s-media.nyc.gov/agencies/lpc/lp/2600.pdf ==References== {{reflist|30em}} == Literature == * Dirk Stichweh: ''New York Skyscrapers''. Prestel Publishing Company, Munich 2009, {{ISBN|3-7913-4054-9}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.in-arch.net/NYC/nyc4.html#78 in-Arch.net: The Sony Building] *[http://www.galinsky.com/buildings/att/ Photos and additional information at Galinsky.com] *[http://www.bluffton.edu/~sullivanm/johnsonburgee/att.html Photos by Johnson Burgee] *[http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20020913061706/http%3A//www.sonywondertechlab.com/ Sony Wonder Technology Lab] {{AT&T}} {{Sony Corp}} [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1984]] [[Category:Postmodern architecture in New York City]] [[Category:Modernist architecture in New York City]] [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Manhattan]] [[Category:Philip Johnson buildings]] [[Category:John Burgee buildings]] [[Category:Sony]] [[Category:AT&T buildings]] [[Category:Midtown Manhattan]] [[Category:Madison Avenue]]

{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Abby Jimenez | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1958|09|25}}entered by family member | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death date and age|2016|02|26|1958|09|25}}entered by family member | death_place = Philippines | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = [[Philippines]] | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = [[Advertising]] | years_active = | employer = | organization = Publicis JimenezBasic
Woo Consulting | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | religion = | spouse = [[Ramon Jimenez, Jr.]],
Philippine tourism secretary | partner = | children = [[Sassa Jimenez]],
fashion designer | parents = | relatives = [[Ramon T. Jimenez]]
father-in-law
prominent labor lawyer | callsign = | awards = Ad Agency
of the year (2007) | signature = | signature_size = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Abby Jimenez''' was an advertising executive in the Philippines. She was a chairman of Publicis JimenezBasic (sometimes ''Jimenez Basic''),{{cite news |title= Nescafé wins the Bronze Prize at the Tambuli Awards |publisher= ''Philippine Star'' |quote= Publicis JimenezBasic Immediate past chairman Abby Jimenez... |date= August 24, 2009 |url= http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=498639&publicationSubCategoryId=78 |accessdate= 2010-12-30 }} an [[advertising agency]] in the [[Philippines]].{{cite news |title=Brandie Tan & Tin Sanchez |publisher=''adobo magazine'' |quote=Tragedies may come in threes, but fortune and fame often come to partnerships of two. ... Mon and Abby Jimenez. |date=2010-12-30 |url=http://www.adobomagazine.com/global/module.php?LM=articles.level3&id=1203353672289 |accessdate=2010-12-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707085010/http://www.adobomagazine.com/global/module.php?LM=articles.level3&id=1203353672289 |archivedate=2011-07-07 }} She and her husband Monet Jimenez were featured on the cover of ''Adobo Magazine'' in February 2009.{{cite news |title= Magazine cover |publisher= ''adobo magazine'' |quote= (note: Monet and Abby Jimenez were pictured on the cover of this magazine) |date= January–February 2009 |url= http://issuu.com/adobomagazine/docs/0109 |accessdate= 2010-12-30 }} Her firm Publicis JimenezBasic with 120 employees managed advertising accounts for Philippine brands such as Decolgen,{{cite news |author= Jack Sotto |title= Decolgen takes humorous approach |publisher= ''campaign'' |quote= Created by local agency Jimenez Basic,. ... The campaign, by Mon and Abby Jimenez, ... |date= 13 June 2007 |url= http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/news/664047/Decolgen-takes-humorous-approach/?DCMP=ILC-SEARCH |accessdate= 2010-12-30 }} Jollibee,{{cite news |author= Nanette Franco- Diyco |title= Christmas wishes with Jollibee |publisher= ''Business World Online'' |quote= Jollibee goes out of its way annually to produce a tug-at-the-heart Christmas commercial ... I’m glad that advertising agency Publicis JimenezBasic selected this theme ... |date= December 9, 2010 |url= http://www.bworldonline.com/cms_assets/printerfriendly_wkndr.php?id=22618 |accessdate= 2010-12-30 }} Skyflakes, and Lucky Me,{{cite news |author=Aye Ubaldo |title=UP Diliman Tops the 11th IMC Students' Competition |publisher=''Philippine Association of National Advertisers Foundation'' (PANA) |quote=... Mon and Abby Jimenez to head MaxMarketing, the planning and research group for JimenezBasic. |date=2010-12-30 |url=http://www.panaf.com.ph/links/news5.php |accessdate=2010-12-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101217093309/http://www.panaf.com.ph/links/news5.php |archivedate=2010-12-17 }} and for clients such as Unilab,{{cite news |author= Nanette A. Franco-Diyco |title= Hard-hitting humor |publisher= ''Business World Weekender'' |quote= Credits. Client-company, Unilab. Cherish Canizares, category marketing manager; Alex Fernandez, marketing director; Ida Atis, brand manager. Advertising agency, Jimenez Basic. Mon and Abby Jimenez |date= June 23, 2007 |url= http://www.bworld.net/Weekender062207/main.php?id=marketing_diyco |accessdate= 2010-12-30 }} Greenwich Pizza,{{cite news |author=Nanette Franco- Diyco |title=Greenwich conquers pizza world |publisher=''Business World Online: Weekender'' |quote=Greenwich and its advertising agency Publicis Jimenez Basic have hit it big with the youth using delectable humor. |date=August 22, 2009 |url=http://www.bworldonline.com/Weekender082109/main.php?id=marketing_diyco |accessdate=2010-12-30 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} and ''Manila Bulletin''.{{cite news |author=Nanette Franco- Diyco |title=The Bulletin on balance |publisher=''Business World Online: Weekender'' |quote=Publicis Jimenez Basic’s newly launched television commercials of Manila Bulletin precisely holler: "There is good news." A |date=August 1, 2009 |url=http://www.bworldonline.com/Weekender073109/main.php?id=marketing_diyco |accessdate=2010-12-30 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In 2011 her husband [[Ramon Jimenez, Jr.]] was chosen to be the tourism secretary for the [[Philippines]].{{cite news |author= Kathrina Alvarez-- Sunnex |title= Tourism Secretary resigns |publisher= ''Sun Star'' |quote= ... advertising executive Ramon Jimenez... |date= August 13, 2011 |url= http://www.sunstar.com.ph/manila/local-news/2011/08/13/no-replacement-yet-resigned-tourism-exec-172833 |accessdate= 2011-08-13 }}{{cite news |author= Aurea Calica |title= P-Noy still looking for next DOT chief |publisher= ''Philippine Star'' |date= August 14, 2011 |url= http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=716532&publicationSubCategoryId=63 |accessdate= 2011-08-13 }} Her firm handled public advocacy campaigns including one to encourage Philippine families to eat meals together.{{cite news |author=Nanette Franco- Diyco |title=Steering the parental ship via advocacy ads |publisher=''Business World Online: Weekender'' |quote=The advocacy campaign of advertising agency Jimenez Basic started several months ago with growing frequency, using traditional media, print, radio, TV and billboards. ... eating together is a simple but effective means for parents to raise happy healthy successful children." |date=September 27, 2008 |url=http://www.bworldonline.com/Weekender092608/main.php?id=marketing_diyco |accessdate=2010-12-30 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Jimenez and her husband began a firm helping clients with media and marketing issues entitled ''Woo Consultants''.{{cite news |title=Back in the game |publisher=''adobo magazine'' |quote=Mon and Abby Jimenez have opened WOO Consultants ... According to Abby Jimenez, WOO is "a marketing and media consultancy, not an ad agency," but agency folks will recognize a few names. ... |date=2011-08-13 |url=http://www.adobomagazine.com/global/module.php?LM=news.level1&id=1244699947795 |accessdate=2011-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316160625/http://www.adobomagazine.com/global/module.php?LM=news.level1&id=1244699947795 |archivedate=2012-03-16 |df= }} She was a judge for advertising awards including the ''Tambuli Awards'' sponsored by the [[University of Asia and the Pacific]].{{cite news |title= University of Asia and the Pacific’s Tambuli Awards 2009 |publisher= ''Tambuli Awards'' |quote= Even then, entries still had to undergo the discernment of the Tambuli Awards 2009’s board of judges composed of the most prestigious figures the awards have ever seen.... Publicis JimenezBasic Immediate Past Chairman Abby Jimenez... |year= 2009 |url= http://www.tambuliawards.com/press.aspx |accessdate= 2010-12-30 }} She spoke at industry conferences.{{cite news |title= 2009 ASAP Conference Business Refreshed Ideas of Advertising Suppliers |publisher= ''Web Phil Info.com Inc.'' |quote= Chief Executive Officers of Woo Consultancy Mon and Abby Jimenez who exposed the ins-and-outs of “Family in Business” and University of Asia and the Pacific Professor, Dr. Bernardo Villegas who tackled “Economic Prospects.” |date= August 25, 2009 |url= http://webphilippines.blogspot.com/2009_08_01_archive.html |accessdate= 2010-12-30 }} In 2007, her agency was named ''Agency of the Year''.{{cite news |author=Nanette Franco- Diyco |title=Agency of the Year |publisher=''Business World Online: Weekender'' |quote=Advertising Agencies of the Philippines). This is the 12th AOY year following more than a decade of glorious wins: ... 2006, Jimenez Basic... |date=September 5, 2009 |url=http://www.bworldonline.com/Weekender090409/main.php?id=marketing_diyco |accessdate=2010-12-30 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite news |title=2007 Agency of the Year |publisher=''Mekeni's Land'' |quote=Congratulations to the 120 member-strong agency under the helm of Mon & Abby Jimenez. |year=2007 |url=http://arcastro57.multiply.com/journal?&page_start=80 |accessdate=2010-12-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714131724/http://arcastro57.multiply.com/journal?&page_start=80 |archivedate=2011-07-14 }} She was the mother of Philippine [[fashion designer]] [[Sassa Jimenez]].{{cite news |author=Lorra Elena Angbue-Te |title=Young designer shows her stuff |publisher=''Philippine Inquirer'' |quote=Twenty-one-year-old Sassa Jimenez, preparing for Philippine Fashion Week, gives off a fresh vibe and talks in a delicate voice, apparently wise beyond her years. ... Her parents, Mon and Abby Jimenez of JimenezBasic, have undoubtedly influenced Sassa’s inclination towards the arts. |date=Oct 16, 2008 |url=http://showbizandstyle.inquirer.net/lifestyle/lifestyle/view/20081016-166791/Young-designer-shows-her-stuff |accessdate=2010-12-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120831193156/http://showbizandstyle.inquirer.net/lifestyle/lifestyle/view/20081016-166791/Young-designer-shows-her-stuff |archivedate=2012-08-31 |df= }} She died in 2016 of lower motor neuron disease. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jimenez, Abby}} [[Category:Filipino businesspeople]] [[Category:Advertising directors]] [[Category:Filipino chairmen of corporations]] [[Category:Filipino women in business]]

{{Infobox Organization |name = American Pet Products Association |image = APPMALogo.JPG |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |motto = |formation = 1958 |extinction = |type = Not for profit |headquarters = [[Stamford, Connecticut]], United States |location = |membership = |language = |leader_title = |leader_name = |key_people = |num_staff = |budget = |website = {{URL|http://www.americanpetproducts.org/}} }}
The '''American Pet Products Association''' <ref>[http://finance.google.com/finance?cid=6878064 Google Finance]</ref><ref>[http://www.americanpetproducts.org APPA Website]</ref> ('''APPA''') is a not-for-profit industry association founded in 1958 and is headquartered in [[Stamford, Connecticut]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.americanpetproducts.org/about_staff.asp|title=Staff Member Directory|website=American Pet Products Association|access-date=2018-08-24}}</ref>[[Stamford, Connecticut|.]] The APPA represents more than 1000 pet product manufacturers, importers of pet products and suppliers of products for non-pet livestock as well.
APPMA supports the interests of its members through public policy, public affairs, and animal awareness. In 2008 it dropped the word ''Manufacturers'' from its name.<ref>[http://media.americanpetproducts.org/press.php?include=138698]</ref>
The APPA organizes the [[Global Pet Expo]] annually. The 2012 expo featured 896 exhibitors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2012/3/prweb9318939.htm|title=Global Pet Expo, the World’s Largest Annual Pet Products Trade Show, Reports Record-Breaking Numbers in Attendance and Booths Sold|agency=PRWeb}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} *{{cite news |first=Patrick J. |last=Lyons |authorlink= |coauthors= |title= Business: Diary; No Jokes, Please, About Working for Scale |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/10/08/business/business-diary-no-jokes-please-about-working-for-scale.html |work=The New York Times |publisher= |date=October 8, 2000 |accessdate=2008-07-08 }}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.americanpetproducts.org}} *[http://www.globalpetexpo.org Global Pet Expo official website] *[http://www.petsaddlife.org Pets Add Life]
[[Category:Industry trade groups based in the United States]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Connecticut]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1958]] [[Category:1958 establishments in the United States]]
{{business-org-stub}} [[Category:Companies based in Stamford, Connecticut]]

The '''Anglo-Soviet Trade Agreement''' was an agreement signed on 16 March 1921 to facilitate trade between Great Britain and the [[Russian Socialist Federal Soviet Republic]]. It was signed by [[Robert Horne, 1st Viscount Horne of Slamannan|Robert Horne]], [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] and [[Leonid Krasin]], Commissar of Foreign Trade.<ref> Misha V. Glenny,"The Anglo-Soviet Trade Agreement, March 1921." ''Journal of Contemporary History'' 5.2 (1970): 63-82. [http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/002200947000500203?journalCode=jcha Abstract]</ref> Lenin's [[New Economic Policy]] downplayed socialism and emphasized business dealings with capitalist countries, in an effort to restart the sluggish Russian economy. Britain was the first country to accept Lenin's offer of a trade agreement. It ended the British blockade, and Russian ports now were open to British ships. Both sides agreed to refrain from hostile propaganda. It amounted to de facto diplomatic recognition and opened a period of extensive trade.<ref>Christine A. White, ''British and American Commercial Relations with Soviet Russia, 1918-1924'' (1992).</ref>
==Background== [[Lloyd George]] first raised the proposal to drop the blockade on Russia, following the [[October Revolution]] at a meeting of the [[Allied Supreme Council]], held on 14 January 1920, four days after the [[Treaty of Versailles]] had been ratified. Originally trade was to be restricted to being with the "Russian people", through [[All Russian Co-operative Society|Centrosoyuz]], the All-Russian Union of Consumer [[Co-operative]] Societies. However, by the end of May 1920, Leonid Krasin had arrived in London and the terms of the agreement had shifted. Also, although originally an ''allied'' proposal, the [[French Third Republic#France and the First World War|French]] declined [[Lord Curzon]]'s invitation to participate, and the [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)#Italy.27s territorial settlements and the reaction|Italians]] sent a [[chargé d'affaires]] who only participated in one session. Meanwhile, the [[Bolshevik]]s, upon hearing of the Supreme Council's intention of lifting of the blockade and developing trade with the Co-operatives, responded by taking Centrosoyuz over. Lenin wrote the executive decree promulgated by the [[Council of People's Commissars]] on 27 January which put this into effect. Krasin and his fellow delegates were nominally co-opted on to the board of Centrosoyuz, maintaining the fiction that negotiations were being carried out with the Co-operatives Union.<ref> Glenny, (1970), pp. 63-82.</ref>
==First phase of negotiations: from 31 May, to 7 July 1920== Krasin was accompanied by [[Viktor Nogin]] to London to engage in the negotiations. The British Cabinet discussed the proposed agreement at [[10 Downing Street]] on 28 May 1920. Lord Curzon had previously briefed the meeting: :'We know from a great variety of sources that the Russian Government is threatened with complete economic disaster, and that it is ready to pay almost any price for the assistance which we - more than anyone else - are in a position to give. We can hardly contemplate coming to its rescue without exacting our price for it, and it seems to me that price can far better be paid in a cessation of Bolshevik hostility in parts of the world important to us, than the ostensible exchange of commodities, the existence of which on any considerable scale in Russia there is grave reason to doubt.'<ref>Cabinet Paper: 'Negotiations with M. Krassin - Note by Lord Curzon'. C.P. 1350, 27 May 1920. CAB. 241106. as quoted ibid</ref>
There were four meetings held on 31 May, 7 June, 16 June, and 29 June. The first two were more formal, but the third meeting consisted only of Lloyd George, Krasin, Sir Robert Horne, [[Philip Kerr, 11th Marquess of Lothian]] and [[Fridtjof Nansen]]. However, the last meeting was to prove crucial. Both Krasin and Lloyd George agreed that there were two principal issues: * Hostile propaganda and subversion * pre-1917 debts to British creditors
Faced with an impending meeting with Britain's allies, Lloyd George drew up a four-point plan: * An armistice and end to hostile propaganda * The exchange of prisoners * Mutual recognition of outstanding debts for goods and services * Exchange of trade missions Krasin was given 7 days in which to reply and provided passage on board [[HMS Vimiera (1917)|HMS Vimiera]] to [[Reval]]. [[Georgy Chicherin]] responded on 7 July agreeing to these terms in principle.
==Second phase of negotiations: from 8 July, to 11 September 1920== [[Lev Kamenev]] was appointed the head of the new negotiating team at Chicherin's insistence over Lenin's objections.
==Third phase of negotiations: from 12 September 1920 to 16 March 1921 ==
Negotiations were long and protracted. [[Lenin]] remarked at the 8th All Russian Congress of Soviets on 21 December 1920: :The treaty, the trade agreement with Britain is not signed yet. At this very moment Krasin is conducting urgent talks on it in London. The British government has handed us its draft, we have given our counterdraft, but it is still obvious that the British government is dragging its feet over the agreement because the reactionary war party is still hard at work there; it has had the upper hand so far and is hindering the conclusion of a trade agreement. It is in our direct interest, and it is our direct duty to give all our support to whatever can help to fortify those parties and groupings who are striving for the signature of this treaty with us.<ref>Lenin, ''Sochinenia'', XLII, 97-8</ref>
[[Ivan Maisky]] was to underline the importance of the agreement thus: :This diplomatic document, though modest in scope, is of truly historic significance. The Anglo-Soviet Trade Agreement was not an ordinary trade treaty with the mere object of regulating commercial operations between two countries; it was an agreement of politico-commercial character: it gave the RSFSR defacto recognition by the most powerful capitalist power in Europe, a power which in those days still successfully contended with the USA for the role of the foremost capitalist country in the world.<ref>I. Maisky, 'Anglo-sovetskoe torgovoe soglashenie 1921 goda', ''Voprosy Istorii'', No. 5, 1957, 76-7.</ref>
==References== * [http://wwi.lib.byu.edu/index.php/Anglo-Soviet_Trade_Agreement Full text] (accessed 28 July 2009) {{reflist}} == Further reading== * White, Christine A. ''British and American Commercial Relations with Soviet Russia, 1918-1924'' (U of North Carolina Press, 1992). [https://www.questia.com/library/2351054/british-and-american-commercial-relations-with-soviet online] [[Category:Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic]] [[Category:Economic history of Russia]] [[Category:History of the Soviet Union and Soviet Russia]] [[Category:Russia–United Kingdom relations]] [[Category:Treaties of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Soviet Union–United Kingdom relations]] [[Category:Foreign trade of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:1921 in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Treaties concluded in 1921]] [[Category:1921 in Russia]] [[Category:Trade in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Trade in Russia]]

The '''Bronfman family''' is a [[History of the Jews in Canada|Canadian Jewish]] [[family]].{{cite web|last=Curtis|first=Christopher G.|title=Bronfman Family|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/articles/bronfman-family |work=The Canadian Encyclopedia |accessdate=22 December 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020061029/http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/articles/bronfman-family|archivedate=October 20, 2013|deadurl=no}} It owes its initial fame to [[Samuel Bronfman]] (1889–1971), who made a fortune in the alcoholic [[distilled beverage]] business during the 20th century through the family's [[Seagram]] Company.{{cite web|last=The Editors of Encyclopædia Britannica|title=Seagram Company Ltd.|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/530859/Seagram-Company-Ltd|work=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=22 December 2013}} The family is of [[Russian Jewish]] and [[History of the Jews in Romania|Romanian Jewish]] ancestry; "they were originally tobacco farmers from [[Bessarabia]]".{{cite news|last1=Weiss|first1=Steven I.|title=For Centuries, Jews Ruled Poland's Liquor Trade. Why Was That Legacy Forgotten?|url=http://www.tabletmag.com/jewish-news-and-politics/165467/jews-and-booze|accessdate=April 10, 2016|work=Tablet|date=March 11, 2014|quote=Even the Bronfmans, the world's most famous liquor magnates, couldn't tie their successes in booze to the legacy of Polish Jewry's tavern-keeping: They were originally tobacco farmers from Bessarabia.}} According to ''[[New York Times]]'' staff reporter, Nathaniel Popper, the Bronfman family is "perhaps the single largest force in the Jewish charitable world."{{cite news|last=Popper|first=Nathaniel|title=Keeping Alive a Philanthropic Family Tradition|url=http://forward.com/articles/3284/keeping-alive-a-philanthropic-family-tradition/|accessdate=24 December 2013|newspaper=The Jewish Daily Forward|date=April 15, 2005}}{{cite news |last=Kandell| first=Jonathan |title=Edgar M. Bronfman, Who Brought Elegance and Expansion to Seagram, Dies at 84|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/23/business/edgar-m-bronfman-who-brought-elegance-and-expansion-to-seagram-dies-at-84.html?hp|accessdate=22 December 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=22 December 2013}} == Family tree == Some of the family members include:
{{Tree list}} * Abraham BRONFMAN ** Ekiel BRONFMAN Born: 16 Nov 1855, Russia. Married: 1880. Died: 24 Dec 1919. Married to Mindel ELMAN. (Born: 25 May 1863. Died: 11 Nov 1918.) *** Abe BRONFMAN Born: 15 Nov 1882, Russia. Married: 1905. Died: 1968. Married to Sophie RASMINSKY. (Died: 1967.) **** Zelia BRONFMAN **** Rona BRONFMAN **** Mildred BRONFMAN **** Beatrice BRONFMAN **** Ruth BRONFMAN{{Tree list/final branch}} *** Harry BRONFMAN Born: 20 Mar 1885, Russia. Married: 1905. Died: 1963. Married to Ann GALLAMAN. (Died: 1970.) **** Allan BRONFMAN Born: 1906. Married: 1931. Died: 1944. Married to Freda BESNER ***** Mitchell BRONFMAN ***** Marion BRONFMAN ***** Beverly BRONFMAN{{Tree list/final branch}} **** Gerald BRONFMAN **** Rona Retta BRONFMAN{{Tree list/final branch}} *** Laura BRONFMAN Born: 1 Jan 1887, Russia. Married: 1911. Died: 1976. Married to Barnett AARON. *** [[Samuel Bronfman|Samuel Miles BRONFMAN Sr.]] Born: 1 Mar 1889, On board ship / born in [[Soroki]], [[Bessarabia]]. Married: 20 Jun 1922, Winnipeg, Man. Died: 10 Jul 1971, Montreal, Que. Married to Spouse: [[Saidye Rosner Bronfman|Saidye ROSNER BRONFMAN]]. (Born: 20 Dec 1896, Plum Coulee, Man. Died: 6 Jul 1995, Montreal, Que.) **** Aileen Minda BRONFMAN Born: 1925. Married: 1953, Paris, France. Died: 1985. Married to Alain Francois DE GUNZBURG. **** [[Phyllis Lambert|Phyllis Barbara BRONFMAN LAMBERT]] Born: 1927. Married to Jean LAMBERT **** [[Edgar Miles Bronfman, Sr.|Edgar Miles BRONFMAN, Sr.]] Born: 1929. Died: 2013. Married to Ann Margaret LOEB from 1953–1973. Married to Carolyn TOWNSHEND from 1973–1974. Married to Rita "Georgianna" Eileen WEBB (dates unknown). Married to [[Jan Aronson|Jan ARONSON]] from 1994–2013; his death. ***** Samuel BRONFMAN ***** [[Edgar Bronfman Jr.|Edgar Miles BRONFMAN, Jr.]] Born 1955. Married to Sherry BREWER from 1979–1991. Married to Clarisa ALCOCK San Román in 1993. ****** [[Benjamin Bronfman|Benjamin Zachary BRONFMAN]] Born 1982. ****** Vanessa Sherry BRONFMAN ****** [[Hannah Bronfman|Hannah Marcina BRONFMAN]] Born: 1988{{Tree list/final branch}} ***** Holly BRONFMAN ***** [[Matthew Bronfman|Matthew BRONFMAN]] ***** Adam Rodgers BRONFMAN ***** [[Sara Bronfman|Sara Rosner BRONFMAN]] Born: 1976. ***** [[Clare Bronfman|Clare BRONFMAN]] Born: 1979. {{Tree list/final branch}} **** [[Charles Bronfman|Charles Rosner BRONFMAN]]. Married to Barbara BAERWALD. Married to [[Andrea Bronfman|Andrea Brett MORRISON]] from 1982–2006. (Born: 1945. Died: 2006.) Married to Bonita ROCHE from 2008–2011. Married to Rita MAYO in 2012. ***** Stephen BRONFMAN ******Coby Bronfman Born 2005 is the fifth son of Matthew bronfman ***** Ellen BRONFMAN{{Tree list/final branch}} *** Jennie BRONFMAN Born: 3 Feb 1891, Manitoba, Canada. *** Bess BRONFMAN Born: 2 Mar 1893, Manitoba, Canada. Died: 1980. Married to Harry Louis DRUXERMAN (Born: 1887. Married: 1916. Died: 1940.) Married to Harry SOFORENKO. (Married: 1954. Died: 1964.) **** Alvin DRUXERMAN **** Jacquelyn Blanche DRUXERMAN{{Tree list/final branch}} *** Allan BRONFMAN Born: 2 Jan 1896, Manitoba, Canada. Married: 28 Jun 1922, Ottawa, Ont. Died: 26 Mar 1980, Montreal, Que. Married to Lucy BILSKY. **** Mona BRONFMAN Born: 1923. Married: 1947. Died: 1950. **** [[Edward Bronfman|Edward Maurice BRONFMAN]] Born: 1927. Died: 2005. **** [[Peter Bronfman|Peter Frederick BRONFMAN]] Born: 1929. Married: 1976. Died: 1 Dec 1996, Toronto, Ont.{{Tree list/final branch}} *** Rose BRONFMAN Born: 3 Feb 1898, Manitoba, Canada. Married: 24 Jun 1922, Winnipeg, Man. Died: 31 May 1988. Married to Maxwell RADY (Born: 24 Nov 1899. Died: 3 Mar 1964.){{Tree list/final branch}} **** Mindel RADY **** Marjorie RADY **** Ernest RADY{{Tree list/final branch}} {{Tree list/end}} == Works or publications == * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oZ5wV7ChUzY Bronfman Family Dynasty] on ''[[Biography (TV series)|Biography]]'' ''(video'' * [http://findingaids.hagley.org/xtf/view?docId=ead/2173.xml Seagram Museum collection] at [[Hagley Museum and Library]] ''(finding aid)'' === Bronfman Family === * Faith, Nicholas. ''[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/63680061 The Bronfmans: The Rise and Fall of the House of Seagram.]'' New York: St. Martin's Press, 2006. {{ISBN|978-0-312-33219-8}}{{cite news|last=Prial|first=Frank J.|title='The Bronfmans' by Nicholas Faith: Whiskey Chasers |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/06/25/books/review/25prial.html|accessdate=24 December 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=June 25, 2006}} * Gittins, Susan. ''[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/35325202 Behind Closed Doors: The Rise and Fall of Canada's Edper Bronfman and Reichmann Empires.]'' Scarborough, Ont: Prentice Hall Canada, 1995. {{ISBN|978-0-131-82189-7}}{{cite news|last=Corelli|first=Adam|title=Legacy of a bootlegger: Canada's giant Edper conglomerate, created by the outcast cousins of the Bronfman drinks dynasty, is in trouble and may be slipping into unfamiliar hands|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/legacy-of-a-bootlegger-canadas-giant-edper-conglomerate-created-by-the-outcast-cousins-of-the-bronfman-drinks-dynasty-is-in-trouble-and-may-be-slipping-into-unfamiliar-hands-adam-corelli-reports-1473003.html|accessdate=24 December 2013|newspaper=The Independent (UK)|date=February 14, 1993}} * MacLeod, Roderick, and Eric John Abrahamson. ''[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/767733690 Spirited Commitment The Samuel and Saidye Bronfman Family Foundation, 1952-2007.]'' Montréal: Published for the Samuel and Saidye Bronfman Foundation by McGill-Queen's University Press, 2010. {{ISBN|978-0-773-58333-7}} * Marrus, Michael R. ''[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/45731472 Samuel Bronfman: The Life and Times of Seagram's Mr. Sam.]'' Hanover: Published by University Press of New England [for] Brandeis University Press, 1991. {{ISBN|978-0-585-26546-9}} * Newman, Peter Charles. ''[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/4629847 Bronfman Dynasty: The Rothschilds of the New World.]'' Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1978. {{ISBN|978-0-771-06758-7}} ** Also published as Newman, Peter Charles. ''[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/503126950 King of the castle: the making of a dynasty : Seagram's and the Bronfman empire.]'' New York: Atheneum, 1979. * ''[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/496911520 Whisky man inside the dynasty of Samuel Bronfman.]'' Kelowna, B.C.: distributed by FilmWest Associates: 1996. (video) ** Video abstract: "Documents the rise to success of the Bronfman Family, who came to Canada as poor immigrants and became rich and powerful through selling (through Prohibition) and distilling whisky (Seagram Company). Family members recall the tough and determined character of Samuel who strove for social acceptance and respectability while alienating many of his family."{{cite web|title=Whisky man : inside the dynasty of Samuel Bronfman|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/whisky-man-inside-the-dynasty-of-samuel-bronfman/oclc/496911520|work=WorldCat|publisher=OCLC|accessdate=25 December 2013}} === Charles Bronfman === * Bronfman, Charles, and Jeffrey Solomon. ''[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/811132960 The Art of Doing Good: Where Passion Meets Action.]'' San Francisco: Jossey-Bass, 2012. {{ISBN|978-1-1182-8574-9}} * Bronfman, Charles, and Jeffrey Solomon. ''[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/319498541 The Art of Giving: Where the Soul Meets a Business Plan.]'' San Francisco, CA: Jossey-Bass, 2010. {{ISBN|978-0-4705-0146-7}} === Edgar Bronfman, Sr. === * Bronfman, Edgar M., and Jan Aronson. ''[http://www.bronfmanhaggadah.com/ The Bronfman Haggadah.]'' [http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/795175261 WorldCat.] New York: Rizzoli International Publications, 2012. {{ISBN|978-0-8478-3968-1}} * Bronfman, Edgar M. ''[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/37315251 Good Spirits: The Making of a Businessman.]'' New York: Putnam, 1998. {{ISBN|978-0-399-14374-8}} * Bronfman, Edgar M., and Beth Zasloff. ''[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/227574539 Hope, Not Fear: A Path to Jewish Renaissance.]'' New York: St. Martin's Press, 2008. {{ISBN|978-0-3123-7792-2}} * Bronfman, Edgar M. ''[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/34553576 The Making of a Jew.]'' New York: Putnam, 1996. {{ISBN|978-0-399-14220-8}} * Bronfman, Edgar M., and Catherine Whitney. ''[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49936061 The Third Act: Reinventing Yourself After Retirement.]'' New York: G. P. Putnam, 2002. {{ISBN|978-0-399-14869-9}} === Saidye Bronfman === * Bronfman, Saidye. ''[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/45465347 My Sam: A Memoir.]'' Erin, Ont: Porcupine's Quill, 1982. Privately printed. One thousand copies have been printed. Written by his wife, Saidye Rosner Bronfman. === Phyllis Lambert === * Lambert, Phyllis, and Barry Bergdoll. ''[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/813392773 Building Seagram.]'' New Haven, Connecticut ; London, England : Yale University Press, 2013. {{ISBN|978-0-300-16767-2}} ** Book abstract: "The [[Seagram building]] rises over New York's [[Park Avenue]], seeming to float above the street with perfect lines of bronze and glass. Considered one of the greatest icons of twentieth-century architecture, the building was commissioned by [[Samuel Bronfman]], founder of the Canadian distillery dynasty Seagram. Bronfman's daughter [[Phyllis Lambert]] was twenty-seven years old when she took over the search for an architect and chose [[Mies van der Rohe]] (1886-1969), a pioneering modern master of what he termed "skin and bones" architecture. Mies, who designed the elegant, deceptively simple thirty-eight story tower along with [[Philip Johnson]] (1906-2005), emphasized the beauty of structure and fine materials, and set the building back from the avenue, creating an urban oasis with the building's plaza. Through her choice, Lambert established her role as a leading architectural patron and singlehandedly changed the face of American urban architecture. Building Seagram is a comprehensive personal and scholarly history of a major building and its architectural, cultural, and urban legacies. Lambert makes use of previously unpublished personal archives, company correspondence, and photographs to tell an insider's view of the debates, resolutions, and unknown dramas of the building's construction, as well as its crucial role in the history of modern art and architectural culture."{{cite web|title=Building Seagram|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/building-seagram/oclc/813392773|work=WorldCat|publisher=OCLC|accessdate=25 December 2013}} == See also == * [[Seagram Building]] * [[Martlet House]] (formerly Seagram House){{cite journal|last=Desjardins|first=Sylvain-Jacques|title=Seagram Building reborn as Martlet House|journal=McGill Reporter|date=March 25, 2004|issue=2003–2004|volume=36|url=https://www.mcgill.ca/reporter/36/13/martlethouse/|accessdate=25 December 2013}} * [[Cemp Investments]] * [[Edper Investments]] * [[The Samuel and Saidye Bronfman Family Foundation]] * [[Rothschild family]] ==Philanthropy== In 1994, the Bronfman family in collaboration with [[McGill University]] in Montreal, Quebec, supported the establishment of the [[McGill Institute for the Study of Canada]] (MISC), a nonpartisan Canadian research institute.{{cite conference |title=Who pays for Canada? Taxes and Fairness |conference=2018 Annual Conference of the McGill Institute for the Study of Canada (MISC) |date=February 23, 2018 |access-date=July 25, 2018|location=Montreal, Quebec |url=https://www.mcgill.ca/misc/files/misc/misc_2018_final_full_report.pdf |format=PDF }}{{rp|3}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/bronfman-family/ Bronfman Family] at [[The Canadian Encyclopedia]] * [https://dr.library.brocku.ca/handle/10464/6247 Seagram Museum Collection RG 490] Brock University Library Digital Repository {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bronfman Family}} [[Category:Bronfman family|*]] [[Category:Business families]] [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:Drink distillers]] [[Category:Jewish-Canadian families]] [[Category:Jewish Canadian history]] [[Category:Canadian people of Russian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Jewish-American families]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=November 2018}} {{EngvarB|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox writer | name = Bryce Courtenay | birth_name = Arthur Bryce Courtenay<ref name=EBA/> | image = Author and ex-creative director, Bryce Courtenay took a seat in Yahoo!'s Big Idea Chair.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1933|08|14}} | birth_place = [[Johannesburg]], South Africa | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2012|11|22|1933|08|14}} | death_place = [[Canberra]], Australia | resting_place = [[Hall Cemetery]] | occupation = Novelist | nationality = South African/Australian | period = 1989–2012 | genre = [[Bildungsroman]], Historical novel | notableworks = | awards = {{awd|[[British Book Awards]]|1990|[[The Power of One (novel)|The Power of One]]}}{{awd|APA [[Who (magazine)|Who Weekly]] Reader's Choice Award|1998|[[Tommo & Hawk]]}}{{awd|APA [[Who (magazine)|Who Weekly]] Reader's Choice Award|1999|[[Jessica (novel)|Jessica]]}}{{awd|APA [[Who (magazine)|Who Weekly]] Reader's Choice Award|2000|[[Jessica (novel)|Jessica]]}} | signature = | website = {{URL|brycecourtenay.com}} }}
'''Arthur Bryce Courtenay''', [[Member of the Order of Australia|AM]] (14 August 1933{{spaced ndash}}22 November 2012) was a [[South African]]/[[Australian]] advertising director and novelist. He is one of Australia's best-selling authors, notable for his book ''[[The Power of One (novel)|The Power of One]]''.
==Background and early years==
Arthur Bryce Courtenay was born in the Lebombo Mountains, South Africa, the son of Maude Greer and Arthur Ryder. Ryder was married with six children, and lived with his family, but also maintained a relationship with Greer, with whom he already had a daughter, Rosemary. Maude Greer gave the surname Courtenay to both her children.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/books/the-man-who-made-christmas-presents-20121123-29xfk.html|newspaper=Sydney Morning Herald|title=The man who 'made Christmas presents'|date=23 November 2012|first=Patricia|last=Maunder|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227054122/http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/books/the-man-who-made-christmas-presents-20121123-29xfk.html|archivedate=27 December 2013}}</ref> Bryce Courtenay spent most of his early years in a small village in the [[Lebombo Mountains]] in the [[Limpopo province]]. He later attended [[King Edward VII School (Johannesburg)|King Edward VII School]].
In 1955, while studying journalism in London, Courtenay met his future wife, Benita Solomon, and they emigrated to Sydney in 1958. They married in 1959 and had three sons – Brett, Adam and Damon.
Courtenay entered the advertising industry and, over a career spanning 34 years, was the Creative Director of [[McCann Erickson]], [[J. Walter Thompson]] and [[George Patterson Y&R|George Patterson Advertising]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saxton.com.au/default.asp?sd8=325|title=Bryce Courtenay AM|work=Speaker details|publisher=Saxton Speakers' Bureau|archivedate=4 December 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111204124816/http://www.saxton.com.au/default.asp?sd8=325}}</ref> His award-winning campaigns included ''[[Louie the Fly]]'' and the original ''[[Milkybar]] Kid'' commercial.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/arts/bryce-courtenay-dies-in-canberra-aged-79/story-e6frg8n6-1226522635053|title=Bryce Courtenay dies in Canberra aged 79|first=Stephen|last=Romei|date=23 November 2013|newspaper=The Australian}}</ref>
Along with [[Geoffry Morgan Pike|Geoff Pike]], Bryce Courtenay developed the concept behind the [[Yowie (chocolate)|Cadbury Yowie]], a chocolate that contained a children's toy, typically an Australian or New Zealand native animal.
On 1 April 1991, Damon (who was born with the blood condition [[haemophilia]]) died at age 24 from [[AIDS-related complications]], contracted through a blood transfusion.
Courtenay divorced Benita in 2000 and acknowledged sexual relationships with other women during their 42-year marriage. Benita Courtenay died on 11 March 2007, at the age of 72, four months after being diagnosed with acute [[myeloid leukaemia]].<ref name="Benita's death">{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/people/sad-serenade-for-courtenay/2007/03/11/1173548008005.html|title=Sad Serenade for Courtenay|last=Sharp|first=Annette|date=12 March 2007|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120130013455/http://www.smh.com.au/news/people/sad-serenade-for-courtenay/2007/03/11/1173548008005.html|archivedate=30 January 2012}}</ref> He later lived in [[Canberra]] with his second wife, Christine Gee.
==Writing== His novels are primarily set in Australia, his adopted country, or South Africa, the country of his birth. His first book, [[The Power of One (novel)|The Power of One]], was published in 1989 and, despite Courtenay's fears that it would never sell, quickly became one of Australia's best-selling books by any living author. The story was made into a [[The Power of One (film)|film]], as well as being re-released in an edition for children.
Courtenay was one of Australia's most commercially successful authors. He built up this success over the long term by promoting himself and developing a relationship with readers as much as marketing his books; for instance, he gave away up to 2,500 books free each year to readers he met in the street.<ref>{{cite news|last=Byrne|first=Jennifer|url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/firsttuesday/s2871243.htm|title=Blockbusters And Bestsellers|work=[[First Tuesday Book Club]]|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121111214538/http://www.abc.net.au/tv/firsttuesday/s2871243.htm|archivedate=11 November 2012|date=11 May 2012|authorlink=Jennifer Byrne}}</ref> However, only ''The Power of One'' has been published in the United States. Courtenay claimed that this was because "American publishers for the most part have difficulties about Australia, they are interested in books in their own country first and foremost. However, we receive many e-mails and letters from Americans who have read my books and I am hoping in the future that publishers will recognize that there is a market for all my books in the U.S."<ref name=EBA>{{citation|url=http://ebookauthor.com.au/index.php/australian-author/Fiction-eBooks/bryce-courtenay-australian-author|title=Bryce Courtenay|publisher=eBooks International|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130501175854/http://ebookauthor.com.au/index.php/australian-author/Fiction-eBooks/bryce-courtenay-australian-author|archivedate=1 May 2013}}</ref>
==Death== In September 2012, Courtenay announced that he was suffering from terminal [[gastric cancer]] and that his last book would be ''[[Jack of Diamonds (novel)|Jack of Diamonds]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/books/months-to-live-bryce-courtenay-reveals-terminal-cancer-20120907-25jtn.html|title='Months to live': Bryce Courtenay reveals terminal cancer|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=7 September 2012|archivedate=5 October 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121005083302/http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/books/months-to-live-bryce-courtenay-reveals-terminal-cancer-20120907-25jtn.html|first=Craig|last=Butt}}</ref> He died on 22 November at his Canberra home.<ref name=abcnews>{{cite news|title=Power of One author Bryce Courtenay dead at 79|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-11-23/bryce-courtenay-dead-at-79/4388010|publisher=ABC News|date=23 November 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130909165340/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-11-23/bryce-courtenay-dead-at-79/4388010|archivedate=9 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|date=22 November 2012|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20457516|title=Australian author Bryce Courtenay dies|archivedate=27 November 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121127040710/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20457516|publisher=BBC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=10849494|title= Bryce Courtenay has died, aged 79|date=23 November 2012|accessdate=27 December 2013|newspaper=The New Zealand Herald}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/books/bryce-courtenay-writes-his-final-chapter-20121123-29xes.html |title=Bryce Courtenay writes his final chapter |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |first1=Jason|last1= Steger |first2=Steve|last2=Dow |date=23 November 2012|archivedate=8 March 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130308230106/http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/books/bryce-courtenay-writes-his-final-chapter-20121123-29xes.html}}</ref>
==Awards and honours== * [[Order of Australia|Member of the Order of Australia (AM)]]: 1995; in recognition of service to advertising and marketing to the community and as an author<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=871132&search_type=quick&showInd=true|title=COURTENAY, Arthur Bryce|work=Australian Honours|publisher=[[Commonwealth of Australia]]|date=12 June 1995|accessdate=5 November 2010}}</ref> * [[Doctor of Letters|Doctor of Letters (D.Litt)]] ([[Honorary degree|honoris causa]]): 2005; from the [[University of Newcastle (Australia)|University of Newcastle]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newcastle.edu.au/Resources/Divisions/Vice-Chancellor/Corporate%20Development%20and%20Community%20Partnerships/Alumni%20unit/honorary-degree-recipients.pdf|title=Honorary Degree Recipients|work=Alumni – Corporate Development and Community Partnerships |publisher=[[University of Newcastle, Australia|University of Newcastle]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314110841/http://www.newcastle.edu.au/Resources/Divisions/Vice-Chancellor/Corporate%20Development%20and%20Community%20Partnerships/Alumni%20unit/honorary-degree-recipients.pdf|archivedate=14 March 2012}}</ref> *[[Doctor of the University|Doctor of the University (D.Univ.)]] ([[Honorary degree|honoris causa]]): 2012; from the [[University of Canberra]] * [[Australia Post]] Literary Legend: 2010; honoured on an Australian postage stamp<ref>{{cite web|url=http://auspost.com.au/priority/issue_48_3.html|title=Bryce Courtenay – Literary legends|work=[[Priority (magazine)|Priority]]|date=March 2010|archivedate=6 March 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306022906/http://auspost.com.au/priority/issue_48_3.html}}</ref>

'''Carl Oscar Collett''' (2 February 1922 – 21 May 2008) was a Norwegian businessperson and politician for the [[Conservative Party (Norway)|Conservative Party]].
He was born in [[Oslo|Kristiania]] as a son of forester [[Oscar Collett]] (1877–1950) and Maria Iversen.<ref name=hvem>{{cite encyclopedia|year=1973|title=Collett, Carl Oscar|encyclopedia=[[Hvem er hvem?]]|editor=Steenstrup, Bjørn|publisher=Aschehoug|location=Oslo|url=http://runeberg.org/hvemerhvem/1973/0111.html|page=111|language=Norwegian|accessdate=13 March 2012}}</ref> He was a grandson of [[Albert Collett]] and nephew of [[Arthur Collett|Arthur]], [[Emil Collett|Emil]], [[Johan Collett (1874–1969)|Johan]] and Axel Collett.
He finished [[Oslo Commerce School]] in 1940 and took the [[examen artium]] in 1941. He graduated from the National Forestry Academy in [[Steinkjer]] in 1943, and took the MBA at [[Harvard Business School]] in 1949. In 1948 he married Dagmar Gunla von Sydow Bødtker, a daughter of [[Henning Bødtker]].<ref name=hvem/>
In 1950 he was hired in the family company [[Firma Albert Collett]]. He was a board member from 1954, and from 1963 to 1971 he owned the company together with Albert P. Collett and manager Andreas Ebbing. In 1971 he was hired as manager of [[Mathiesen Eidsvold Værk]].<ref name=hvem/> In 1979 he went on to the Forest Industry Research Council.<ref>{{cite news|title=60 år|work=[[Aftenposten]]|language=Norwegian|date=2 February 1982|page=10}}</ref>
Collett chaired the Conservative Party in [[Nord-Trøndelag]] from 1955 to 1957, and was a member of the party's central board the last year. He was a [[municipal council (Norway)|municipal council]] member in the municipality of [[Klinga (municipality)|Klinga]] from 1960 to 1964 and in [[Namsos]] municipality from 1964 to 1968. He was a working committee member of the employers' association {{lang|no|[[Skogbrukets Landsforening|Skogbrukets Arbeidsgiverforening]]}} from 1960 to 1970, chairing the organization from 1965 to 1969. He was a board member of the [[Norwegian Forestry Association|Forestry Association of 1950]] from 1959 to 1971, chairing the organization from 1966 to 1970.<ref name=hvem/> He became a member of the gentlemen's skiing club [[SK Fram (Oslo)|SK Fram]] in 1972.<ref>{{cite book|editor=Qvale, Fredrik|editor-link=Fredrik Qvale|year=1989|title=Skiklubben Fram 100 år|language=Norwegian|pages=9–11}}</ref> He was also a supervisory council member of [[Forsikringsselskapet Viking]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Forsikringsselskapet Viking utdeler 8 pst.|work=[[Aftenposten]]|language=Norwegian|date=5 June 1969|page=12}}</ref>
He died in May 2008 and was buried at [[Ris, Oslo|Ris]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.disnorge.no/gravminner/index.php?language=engelsk|title=Cemeteries in Norway|publisher=DIS-Norge|accessdate=17 March 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox GAA player | code= Football | sport = Gaelic football | image = | name = Ciarán Maher | irish = Ciarán Ó Meachair | feet = | inches = | occupation = Business owner | county = Boston | province = Leinster | club = [[Ballyboden St. Enda's GAA|Ballyboden St. Enda's]]
[[Shannon Blues GFC|Shannon Blues]] | clubs = | clyears = | clapps(points) = | clcounty = 3 | clprovince= | clallireland = | counties = [[Dublin GAA|Dublin]] | icposition = Right corner-forward | icyears = 1983-1984 | icapps(points) = | icprovince = 0 | icallireland = 1 | nfl = 0 | allstars = 0 | clupdate = | icupdate = | birth_date=1962 | death_place=[[Marshfield, Massachusetts|Marshfield]], [[Massachusetts]], [[United States]] | death_date=10 December 2012 (aged 50) | birth_place=[[Knocklyon]], [[Dublin]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] }} '''Ciarán Maher''' (1962 - 10 December 2012) was an [[Irish people|Irish]] [[Gaelic football]]er who played as a right corner-forward for the [[Dublin GAA|Dublin]] senior team.{{cite news|url=http://www.hoganstand.com/dublin/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=182349|title=The late Kieran Maher|date=11 December 2012|publisher=Hogan Stand website|accessdate=16 December 2012}} Maher made his first appearance for the team during the [[All-Ireland Senior Football Championship 1983|1983 championship]] and was a regular member of the extended panel until for just two seasons. During that time he won one [[All-Ireland Senior Football Championship|All-Ireland]] medal on the field of play. At club level Maher was a three-time [[Boston Senior Football Championship|county club championship]] medalist with [[Shannon Blues GFC|Shannon Blues]] in Boston. He began his club career with [[Ballyboden St. Enda's GAA|Ballyboden St. Enda's]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Dublin Football Team 1983}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Maher, Ciaran}} [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:Ballyboden St. Enda's Gaelic footballers]] [[Category:Dublin inter-county Gaelic footballers]] [[Category:Irish businesspeople]] [[Category:Winners of one All-Ireland medal (Gaelic football)]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox Minister | name = Claudio Aranzadi | image = (Aranzadi) Rosa Conde en la rueda de prensa posterior al Consejo de Ministros acompañada del ministro de Industria y Energía. Pool Moncloa. 30 de junio de 1989 (cropped).jpeg | imagesize = | caption = Aranzadi in [[La Moncloa]] (June 1989) | office = [[Ministry of Industry (Spain)|Minister of Industry and Energy]] | primeminister= [[Felipe González Márquez]] | predecessor = | successor=[[Juan Manuel Eguiagaray]] | term_start=1988 | term_end=1993 | birth_date ={{birth date and age|1946|10|9|df=yes}} | birth_place =[[Bilbao]] | death_date = | death_place = | restingplace = | party = [[Spanish Socialist Workers' Party]] | residence = | alma_mater = Bilbao Industrial Engineering School
[[University of Paris I]] | spouse = | nationality = [[Spanish people|Spanish]] | religion= | children = | website = | footnotes = }} '''José Claudio Aranzadi Martínez''' (born 9 October 1946) is a Spanish engineer, businessman and politician. He served as industry minister from 1988 to 1993. ==Early life and education== Aranzadi was born in [[Bilbao]] on 9 October 1946.{{cite book|title=The International Who's Who 2004|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=neKm1X6YPY0C&pg=PA58|accessdate=15 January 2014|year=2003|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-1-85743-217-6|page=58}} He holds a bachelor's degree in industrial engineering from Bilbao Industrial Engineering School. Then he received an economics degree from [[University of Paris I|the University of Paris I]].{{cite web|title=Claudio Aranzadi|url=http://www.barcelonagse.eu/faculty.php?id=73|work=Barcelona GSE|accessdate=17 September 2013}} ==Career== Aranzadi began his career at the ministry of industry. Then he moved to [[Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria]] where he served as a researcher. Next he was named deputy economic advisor in the Bancaya Group. In 1984, he was made deputy chairman of [[Instituto Nacional de Industria]] (INI), a vast state holding company of Spain. He became the chairman of INI on 1 August 1986, replacing Luis Carlos Croissier Batista in the post.{{cite web|title=History:Grupo INI|url=http://www.sepi.es/default.aspx?cmd=0004&IdContent=345&idLanguage=_EN|work=SEPI|accessdate=17 September 2013}} Aranzadi supported [[privatization]] during his term at the INI, arguing that it was a powerful means of organizing asset portfolios and investment strategies.{{cite book|author1=John Vickers|author2=Vincent Wright|title=The Politics of Privatisation in Western Europe|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=e7miKwzjQRUC&pg=PA6|accessdate=15 January 2014|date=18 February 1989|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-203-98923-4|page=6}} His tenure at the INI lasted until 12 July 1988 when he was succeeded by Jorge Mercader Miró as INI chairman. Aranzadi served as the minister of industry and energy from 1988 to 1991 in the cabinet led by [[Prime Minister of Spain|Prime Minister]] [[Felipe Gonzalez]].{{cite news|title=Gonzales names new cabinet|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1988/Gonzalez-Names-New-Cabinet/id-a5e2290f3e50329e7a6fcf3dbe9dd56c|accessdate=17 September 2013|work=Associated Press|date=9 July 1988}} He was a member of the [[Spanish Socialist Workers' Party]], being one of the right-wing leaders.{{cite book|author=Paul Heywood|title=Politics and Policy in Democratic Spain: No Longer Different?|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VUAAAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA164|accessdate=15 January 2014|date=5 November 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-23142-2|page=164}} He was appointed minister of industry, trade and tourism in 1991 in the Gonzalez cabinet. In 1993, [[Juan Manuel Eguiagaray]] replaced Aranzadi as minister.{{cite web|title=Global businesses, global lobbies|url=http://www.economia.unam.mx/amhe/pdfs/bol_n_9_dic_2008_anexo.pdf|work=Universidad Nacional|accessdate=17 September 2013|author=Paloma Fernández Pérez|year=2008}} After leaving office Aranzadi was appointed permanent representative of Spain to the [[OECD]] in 1993.{{cite web|title=New Spanish ambassador to the OECD|url=http://search.oecd.org/officialdocuments/displaydocumentpdf/?cote=SG/PRESS(93)63&docLanguage=En|work=OECD|accessdate=17 September 2013|date=3 November 1993}} He succeeded Eloy Ibanez in the post. He has been the chairman of BravoSolution España and advisor for Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria. He is a partner of Enerma Consultores, a member of the advisory board of CDTI (Centro para el Desarrollo Tecnólogico Industrial) and of the advisory board for the Spanish Energy Outlook 2030. In addition, he is also on the advisory board of various firms. ==Personal life== Aranzadi is married and has one child, a daughter. ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aranzadi, Claudio}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Bilbao]] [[Category:University of Paris alumni]] [[Category:Spanish engineers]] [[Category:Spanish economists]] [[Category:Spanish businesspeople]] [[Category:Government ministers of Spain]] [[Category:Spanish Socialist Workers' Party politicians]] [[Category:Spanish corporate directors]] [[Category:Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development officials]] [[Category:Spanish expatriates in France]]
