page.title: Small and Medium Enterprise Development Authority

revision.text:
'''Small and Medium Enterprises Development Authority (SMEDA)'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pakobserver.net/smeda-promoting-entrepreneurship-in-agriculture-sector/|title=SMEDA promoting entrepreneurship in agriculture sector - PakObserver|date=13 April 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1380702|title=Smeda, Mardan varsity to build capacity of SMEs|first=Bureau|last=Report|date=4 January 2018|publisher=}}</ref> is an autonomous institution of the Government of Pakistan under [[Ministry of Industries and Production (Pakistan)|Ministry of Industries and Production]]. SMEDA was established in October 1998 for encouraging and facilitating the development and growth of [[small and medium enterprises]] in the country.<ref>http://plan9.pitb.gov.pk/starting-up-list-of-all-incubators-and-accelerators-in-pakistan/</ref>
SMEDA is not only an SME policy-advisory body for the government of Pakistan but also facilitates other stakeholders in addressing their SME development agendas.
==See also== [[Pakistan Industrial Development Corporation]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.smeda.org.pk/ Small and Medium Enterprise Development Authority (SMEDA)]
{{Ministry of Industries and Production (Pakistan)|state=autocollapse}} [[Category:Pakistan federal departments and agencies]] [[Category:1998 establishments in Pakistan]] [[Category:Government agencies established in 1998]] [[Category:Organizations related to small and medium-sized enterprises]] [[Category:Business incubators of Pakistan]]
{{Pakistan-gov-stub}}

{{Infobox royalty | name = Talita von Fürstenberg | title = | image = | caption = | birth_name = Talita Natasha Prinzessin zu Fürstenberg{{cite web|title=Person Page|url=http://www.thepeerage.com/p16328.htm#c163276.1|website=www.thepeerage.com|accessdate=17 August 2016|language=English|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160731223514/http://thepeerage.com/p16328.htm#c163276.1|archivedate=31 July 2016|df=}}{{cite web|title=Talita Natasha, princess of Fürstenberg, * 1999 {{!}} Geneall.net|url=http://geneall.net/en/name/423471/talita-natasha-princess-of-furstenberg/|website=geneall.net|accessdate=17 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818115619/http://geneall.net/en/name/423471/talita-natasha-princess-of-furstenberg/|archivedate=18 August 2016|df=}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1999|5|7}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | house = [[House of Fürstenberg|Fürstenberg]] | father = [[Prince Alexander von Fürstenberg]] | mother = [[Alexandra von Fürstenberg|Alexandra Miller]] | siblings = | spouse = | issue = | occupation = Fashion model
Socialite }} '''Princess Talita Natasha von Fürstenberg''' (born '''Talita Natasha Prinzessin zu Fürstenberg''' on May 7, 1999) is an American socialite and fashion model.{{cite web|last1=Malle|first1=Chloe|last2=Barsamian|first2=Edward|title=Frigid Festivities: Diane von Furstenberg’s Post-Show Dinner and Edun’s Family-Style Celebration|url=http://www.vogue.com/10984867/diane-von-furstenberg-alexa-chung-edun-parties-fashion-week/|website=Vogue|publisher=Condé Nast|accessdate=30 April 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219110644/http://www.vogue.com/10984867/diane-von-furstenberg-alexa-chung-edun-parties-fashion-week|archivedate=19 February 2015|language=English|date=16 February 2015}} She is the granddaughter of fashion designers [[Diane von Fürstenberg]] and [[Prince Egon von Fürstenberg]].{{cite web|last1=Stern|first1=Carly|title=It's good to be rich! Bikini-clad Princess Olympia of Greece enjoys lavish Bahamas getaway with cousin Talita von Furstenberg and Elle Macpherson's son after spending the summer jet-setting around the Mediterranean|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-3202287/Princess-Olympia-Greece-enjoys-Bahamas-Elle-Macpherson-s-son-Flynn-Busson.html|website=MailOnline|accessdate=30 April 2016|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150819145534/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-3202287/Princess-Olympia-Greece-enjoys-Bahamas-Elle-Macpherson-s-son-Flynn-Busson.html|archivedate=19 August 2015|language=English|date=18 August 2015}} ==Personal life== Princess Talita Natasha von Fürstenberg was born on May 7, 1999 to [[Prince Alexander von Fürstenberg]] and [[Alexandra von Fürstenberg|Alexandra Miller]].{{cite web|url=https://www.modaoperandi.com/editorial/mother-daughter-mother-s-day|title=Mother / Daughter Mother's Day - Moda Operandi|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161012083440/https://www.modaoperandi.com/editorial/mother-daughter-mother-s-day|archivedate=2016-10-12|df=}} On her father's side she is a member of the German [[Fürstenberg (princely family)|Princely Family of Fürstenberg]] and heiress of the Italian [[Agnelli family]] (her great-great grandparents were [[Edoardo Agnelli (industrialist)|Eduardo Agnelli]] and [[Virginia Bourbon del Monte|Princess Virginia Bourbon del Monte]]). Her paternal grandparents are fashion designers [[Diane von Fürstenberg]] and [[Egon von Fürstenberg|Prince Egon von Fürstenberg]].{{cite web|title=Meet Diane von Furstenberg's Super Glamorous Granddaughter Talita|url=http://insider.teenvogue.com/fashion/2013-10/talita-von-furstenberg/|website=Teen Vogue Insider|publisher=Condé Nast Digital|accessdate=30 April 2016|language=English|date=October 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211155231/http://popmania.com/talita-von-furstenberg-2016/|archivedate=11 February 2017|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.whowhatwear.com/talita-von-furstenberg-style|title=This 17-Year-Old Royal Has the Coolest Style|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018205125/http://www.whowhatwear.com/talita-von-furstenberg-style|archivedate=2016-10-18|df=}} Her maternal grandfather is billionaire businessman [[Robert Warren Miller]]. She has a younger brother, Prince Tassilo Egon Maximilian von Fürstenberg, and a younger half brother, Prince Leon von Fürstenberg.{{cite web|title=Diane Von Furstenberg's A Granny Again!|url=http://perezhilton.com/cocoperez/2012-08-01-diane-von-furstenberg-is-a-grandma-again/|website=PerezHilton|publisher=PerezHilton.com|accessdate=30 April 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130613140453/http://perezhilton.com/cocoperez/2012-08-01-diane-von-furstenberg-is-a-grandma-again#.VySjlo-cFPY|archivedate=13 June 2013|language=English|date=1 October 2012}} She is the niece of [[Pia Getty]], [[Marie-Chantal, Crown Princess of Greece|Marie-Chantal, Crown Princess of Greece, Princess of Denmark]], and [[Princess Tatiana von Fürstenberg]]. She is a second cousin once-removed of [[Coco Brandolini d'Adda]] and [[Bianca Brandolini d’Adda]]. She graduated in 2017 from the [[Brentwood School (Los Angeles)|Brentwood School]] in Los Angeles, where she was a member of the [[fencing]] team.{{cite web|url=https://askfred.net/Results/results.php?tournament_id=26780|title=SoCal Scholastic League Individual Epee/Saber #1 Results :: FRED: Fencing Tournaments|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161116164353/https://askfred.net/Results/results.php?tournament_id=26780|archivedate=2016-11-16|df=}} She currently attends [[Georgetown University]] with her cousin, [[Prince Constantine Alexios of Greece and Denmark]], where she is studying international relations.http://www.vogue.co.uk/article/talita-von-furstenberg-interview{{Cite web |url=http://guestofaguest.com/new-york/nyc-society/who-is-talita-von-furstenberg&slide=1 |title=Who Is Talita von Furstenberg? |website=Guest of a Guest |language=en |access-date=2017-08-20 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211155231/http://popmania.com/talita-von-furstenberg-2016/ |archivedate=2017-02-11 |df= }} == Career == Von Fürstenberg has interned for Teen Vogue, as well as having been active in her grandmother's fashion house, [[DvF]].{{cite web|last1=Binkley|first1=Christina|title=Diane von Furstenberg Mulls Label’s Future|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/diane-von-furstenberg-mulls-future-of-her-label-1414613114|website=The Wall Street Journal|publisher=Dow Jones & Company, Inc|accessdate=30 April 2016|language=English|date=29 October 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160402051753/http://www.wsj.com/articles/diane-von-furstenberg-mulls-future-of-her-label-1414613114|archivedate=2 April 2016|df=}}{{subscription required}}{{cite web|last1=Rosenbloom|first1=Stephanie|title=Tightening Belts? She’s the Expert|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/19/business/19diane.html?_r=1|website=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|accessdate=30 April 2016|language=English|date=18 July 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820120353/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/19/business/19diane.html?_r=1|archivedate=20 August 2017|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.instyle.com/celebrity/17-celebrity-kids-you-need-to-know|title=17 Stunning Celeb Kids You Need to Know Now|publisher=}} In 2015 she was featured on the cover of the October issue and had her own spread for [[Tatler|Tatler Magazine]].{{cite web|title=Introducing Talita von Furstenberg|url=https://models.com/work/tatler-introducing-talita-von-furstenberg|website=models.com|accessdate=30 April 2016|language=English|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305070139/https://models.com/work/tatler-introducing-talita-von-furstenberg|archivedate=5 March 2016|df=}}{{cite web|title=Tatler Magazine October 2015 – Talita Von Furstenberg by Jason Kim|url=http://fashioneditorials.com/2015/09/17/tatler-magazine-october-2015-talita-von-furstenberg-by-jason-kim/|website=FASHIONEDITORIALS.COM|publisher=Fashioneditorials.com|accessdate=30 April 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304205549/http://fashioneditorials.com/2015/09/17/tatler-magazine-october-2015-talita-von-furstenberg-by-jason-kim/|archivedate=4 March 2016|language=English|date=17 September 2015}} She has also been featured in [[Teen Vogue]].{{cite web|url=http://teenvogue.tumblr.com/post/64720632657/talita-von-furstenberg|title=Teen Vogue — The life of Talita von Furstenberg can...|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170320143501/http://teenvogue.tumblr.com/post/64720632657/talita-von-furstenberg|archivedate=2017-03-20|df=}} In 2016, von Fürstenberg worked as an intern for [[Hillary Clinton]]'s [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016|presidential campaign]].{{cite web|url=http://popmania.com/talita-von-furstenberg-2016/|title=This Famous Designer's Granddaughter Is Your New Style Crush|date=15 August 2016|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211155231/http://popmania.com/talita-von-furstenberg-2016/|archivedate=11 February 2017|df=}} In April 2016, von Fürstenberg was featured in ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' alongside two of her first cousins, [[Isabel Getty]] and [[Princess Maria-Olympia of Greece and Denmark]].https://www.vanityfair.com/style/2016/03/miller-cousins-society-social-media In 2017 she walked the runway for [[Dolce & Gabbana]] during [[Milan Fashion Week]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tmatalentmanagement.co.uk/controversial-french-model-16-who-was-dubbed-the-most-beautiful-girl-in-the-world-at-the-age-of-six-walks-the-runway-for-dolce-gabbana-at-milan-fashion-week/|title=Controversial French model, 16, who was dubbed the 'most beautiful girl in the world' at the age of SIX walks the runway for Dolce & Gabbana at Milan Fashion Week - TMA Talent Management|date=25 September 2017|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.wmagazine.com/story/dolce-gabbanas-models-milan-fashion-week-show|title=Dolce & Gabbana's List of Models Has to Be Seen to Be Believed|first=Kyle|last=Munzenrieder|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-4915008/Celebrity-kids-walk-Dolce-Gabbana-Millennials-runway.html|title=See aaallll the celebrity kids who walked in the Dolce & Gabbana show|publisher=}} In 2018 she was named the new [[muse]] for DvF.http://www.vogue.co.uk/article/talita-von-furstenberg-interview ==Family tree== |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. '''Princess Talita von Fürstenberg''' |2= 2. [[Prince Alexander von Fürstenberg]] |3= 3. [[Alexandra von Fürstenberg|Alexandra Miller]] |4= 4. [[Prince Egon von Fürstenberg]] |5= 5. [[Diane von Fürstenberg|Diane Simone Michelle Halfin]] |6= 6. [[Robert Warren Miller]] |7= 7. Marie Chantal Pesantes |8= 8. [[:de:Tassilo Fürstenberg|Prince Tassilo of Fürstenberg]] |9= 9. [[Agnelli family|Clara Agnelli]] |10= 10. Leon Halfin |11= 11. Liliane Nahmias |12= 12. Ellis Warren Appleton Miller |13= 13. Sophia June Squarebriggs |14= 14. Servando Pesantes Chanduy |15= 15. Beatriz Becerra |16= 16. Prince Karl Emil of Fürstenberg |17= 17. Countess Maria Matilda [[Festetics family|Festetics de Tolna]] |18= 18. [[Edoardo Agnelli (industrialist)|Edoardo Agnelli]] |19= 19. [[Virginia Bourbon del Monte|Princess Virginia Bourbon del Monte]] |20= 20. Shmaya Halfin |21= 21. Sara Halfin |24= 24. Ellis John Springer Miller |25= 25. Blanche Louise Appleton |26= 26. revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox person | image = Teresa Heinz Kerry 2013.jpg | caption = Heinz in 2013 | birth_name = Maria Teresa Thierstein Simões-Ferreira | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1938|10|5}}{{cite web|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2004/09/27/the-candidates-wife|title=The Candidate's Wife|last=Thurman|first=Judith|publisher=The New Yorker|access-date=August 24, 2018|date=September 27, 2004}} | birth_place = [[Maputo|Lourenço Marques]], [[Portuguese Mozambique|Portuguese East Africa]]
(now [[Maputo]], [[Mozambique]]) | nationality = American and Portuguese | residence = [[Fox Chapel, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | education = {{plainlist}} * [[University of the Witwatersrand]] (B.A.) * [[Faculty of Translation and Interpreting of the University of Geneva|University of Geneva, School of Translation and Interpretation]] (M.A.) {{endplainlist}} | other_names = Teresa Heinz Kerry | occupation = Businesswoman, philanthropist | net worth = US$1 billion (2008){{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2008/10/billionaires08_Teresa-F-Heinz-Kerry_UZ1H.html |title=#1062 Teresa F Heinz Kerry |website=Forbes.com |date=2008-02-11 |accessdate=2017-01-26}} | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] (2003–present) | spouse = {{plainlist}} * {{marriage|[[John Heinz]]|1966|1991|end={{abbr|d.|died}}}} * {{marriage|[[John Kerry]]|1995}} {{endplainlist}} | children = 3, including [[André Heinz|André]] and [[Christopher Heinz|Christopher]] }} '''Teresa Heinz''' (born '''Maria Teresa Thierstein Simões-Ferreira'''; October 5, 1938),{{cite web|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2004/09/27/the-candidates-wife|title=The Candidate's Wife|last=Thurman|first=Judith|publisher=The New Yorker|access-date=August 24, 2018|date=September 27, 2004}}{{cite news | title = With Teresa, expect an unconventional campaign | first = Jill | last = Lawrence | date = May 26, 2004 | accessdate = July 29, 2006 | url = https://www.usatoday.com/news/politicselections/nation/president/2004-05-23-heinz-kerry-cover_x.htm | work=USA Today}} also known as '''Teresa Heinz Kerry''', is an American businesswoman and philanthropist of Portuguese descent. Heinz was the widow of former [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[John Heinz]] and is the wife of former [[United States Secretary of State|U.S. Secretary of State]], longtime U.S. Senator, and [[United States presidential election, 2004|2004]] Democratic presidential nominee [[John Kerry]]. Heinz serves as Chair of the [[Heinz Endowments]] and the Heinz Family Philanthropies. ==Early life== Maria Teresa Thierstein Simões-Ferreira was born in the city of Lourenço Marques (later renamed [[Maputo]]) in the colony of [[Portuguese Mozambique]] (which later became the nation of [[Mozambique]]).{{cite web|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2004/09/27/the-candidates-wife|title=The Candidate's Wife|last=Thurman|first=Judith|publisher=The New Yorker|access-date=August 24, 2018|date=September 27, 2004}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.hfp.heinz.org/aboutus/teresaheinz_01.html|title=Heinz Family Philanthropies - Teresa Heinz Biography|date=2004-08-12|access-date=2017-11-21|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040812144600/http://www.hfp.heinz.org/aboutus/teresaheinz_01.html|archivedate=August 12, 2004|df=mdy-all}} Her parents were Dr. José Simões-Ferreira, Jr.,{{cite web|url=http://www.geneall.net/P/per_page.php?id=241307|title=Genea Portugal – José Simões-Ferreira Júnior (Portuguese genealogical site)}} – according to {{cite book|url=http://www.dislivro.pt/detalhes_livros.asp?Cat_Id=1001&offset=15&Product_Id=190|title=The Portuguese Genealogy of Teresa Heinz Kerry|publisher=Dislivro, Lda.|location=Lisbon|year=2004|isbn=972-8876-11-4}} a "Portuguese-born oncologist"{{cite web|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2004/09/27/the-candidates-wife|title=The Candidate's Wife|last=Thurman|first=Judith|publisher=The New Yorker|access-date=August 24, 2018|date=September 27, 2004}} and tropical disease specialist, and Irene Thierstein, a Portuguese and British{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2004/ALLPOLITICS/07/27/dems.teresa/index.html|title=Teresa Heinz Kerry promotes 'women's voices'|last=Loughlin|first=Sean|publisher=CNN|accessdate=October 27, 2008|date=July 28, 2004}} national.{{cite web|url=http://www.geneall.net/P/per_page.php?id=241308|title=Irene Thierstein (Portuguese genealogy site)}} – according to [http://www.dislivro.pt/detalhes_livros.asp?Cat_Id=1001&offset=15&Product_Id=190 "The Portuguese Genealogy of Teresa Heinz Kerry"], Lisbon, 2004. Irene Thierstein's father "was the scion of Swiss-German family living on Malta, and her mother was the half-French, half-Italian daughter of an Alexandrian shipowner who traded with Russia during the Crimean War;{{cite web|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2004/09/27/the-candidates-wife|title=The Candidate's Wife|last=Thurman|first=Judith|publisher=The New Yorker|access-date=August 24, 2018|date=September 27, 2004}} both emigrated to Portuguese East Africa.{{cite web|url=http://www.geneall.net/W/per_page.php?id=314687|title=Alberto Thierstein (Portuguese genealogy site)}} – according to [http://www.dislivro.pt/detalhes_livros.asp?Cat_Id=1001&offset=15&Product_Id=190 "The Portuguese Genealogy of Teresa Heinz Kerry"], Lisbon 2004.{{cite web|url=http://www.geneall.net/W/per_page.php?id=314688|title=Maria Burló (Portuguese genealogy site)}} – according to [http://www.dislivro.pt/detalhes_livros.asp?Cat_Id=1001&offset=15&Product_Id=190 "The Portuguese Genealogy of Teresa Heinz Kerry"], Lisbon 2004. In 1960, Simões-Ferreira earned a Bachelor of Arts in [[Romance languages|Romance Languages]] and Literature from the [[University of the Witwatersrand]], [[Johannesburg]], South Africa. In 1963, she graduated from the School of Translation and Interpretation at the [[University of Geneva]] and moved to the United States to be an [[interpreter]] at the United Nations. ==Marriages, children, and personal life== On February 5, 1966, at [[Pittsburgh|Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania's]] gothic [[Heinz Chapel]] on the campus of the [[University of Pittsburgh]], Simões-Ferreira married future U.S. Senator [[John Heinz]], an heir to the [[H. J. Heinz Company]]. In 1971, Teresa Heinz became a [[naturalized United States citizen]]. The couple had three sons: *Henry John Heinz IV (born November 4, 1966) *[[André Heinz|André Thierstein Heinz]] (born December 9, 1969) *[[Christopher Heinz|Christopher Drake Heinz]] (born March 20, 1973) [[File:Secretary Kerry and his Wife, Teresa Heinz Kerry, Enjoy Their Grandson.jpg|thumb|right|Teresa Heinz Kerry and Secretary Kerry enjoy time with her grandson]] In 1990, Teresa Heinz met Senator Kerry at an [[Earth Day]] rally. This was the only reported time the two met before Senator Heinz died in a plane crash on April 4, 1991. In 1992, Teresa Heinz met Kerry again, this time at the [[Earth Summit]] in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Heinz was a member of a [[United States Department of State|State Department]] delegation appointed by then-[[President of the United States|President]] [[George H. W. Bush]]. The two began courting in 1993 and were married May 26, 1995, in [[Nantucket, Massachusetts]]. Choosing to remain registered as a Republican until [[John Kerry presidential campaign, 2004|John Kerry's presidential bid in 2004]], Heinz retained the name Teresa Heinz. In May 2004, she said:
"My legal name is still Teresa Heinz. Teresa Heinz Kerry is my name... for politics. Just so people don't ask me questions about so and so is so and so's wife or this and that. Teresa Heinz is what I've been all my growing-up life, adult life, more than any other name. And it's the name of my boys, you know ?... So, that's my legal name and that's my office name, my Pittsburgh name."
In addition to Portuguese (her native language),http://old.post-gazette.com/nation/20020605teresanat1p1.asp Heinz speaks English, Spanish, French, and Italian.http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/on_the_trail/2004/09/the_foreign_wives_club.html She is Roman Catholic.{{cite web|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2004/09/27/the-candidates-wife|title=The Candidate's Wife|last=Thurman|first=Judith|publisher=The New Yorker|access-date=August 24, 2018|date=September 27, 2004}} ===Health=== In December 2009, Heinz revealed that she was being treated for breast cancer.{{cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/health/article/0,8599,1949836,00.html | work=Time|title=Teresa Heinz Treated for Breast Cancer|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091226035420/http://www.time.com/time/health/article/0,8599,1949836,00.html|archivedate=December 26, 2009 }} Heinz indicated that she had undergone several lumpectomies and would be following up with a targeted type of radiation therapy treatment called accelerated partial breast irradiation (APBI).https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gSlEyIlyRzEbDZkRWbVe4kxaVMjAD9COR5300 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091228010358/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gSlEyIlyRzEbDZkRWbVe4kxaVMjAD9COR5300 |date=December 28, 2009 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.rtanswers.org/treatmentinformation/cancertypes/breast/accelerated.aspx |title=Radiation Therapy for Breast Cancer: Accelerated Partial Breast Irradiation |publisher=Rtanswers.org |date=June 16, 2010 |accessdate=November 13, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928133238/http://www.rtanswers.org/treatmentinformation/cancertypes/breast/accelerated.aspx |archivedate=September 28, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} On July 7, 2013, Heinz was taken by ambulance to [[Nantucket Cottage Hospital]] after showing symptoms consistent with a seizure. She was described as being in "critical but stable" condition. Heinz was then flown to [[Massachusetts General Hospital]] for further medical treatment and tests. Her condition was upgraded to fair the next day,{{cite news|title=Teresa Heinz Kerry upgraded to fair condition|url=http://www.boston.com/news/source/2013/07/teresa_heinz_kerry_upgraded_to_fair_condition.html|publisher=Boston.com|accessdate=8 July 2013|first=Angela|last=Nelson|date=July 8, 2013}}{{cite news|title=Teresa Heinz Kerry showed symptoms of seizure|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-57592621/reports-teresa-heinz-kerry-showed-symptoms-of-seizure/|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=July 8, 2013}} and doctors were able to rule out a heart attack, brain tumor, stroke, and other triggers.{{cite web|last=Edwards|first=Breanna|title=Aide: Teresa Heinz Kerry improving|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/07/aide-teresa-heinz-kerry-improves-93897.html?hp=r22|publisher=POLITICO|accessdate=July 10, 2013}} On July 11, she was transferred to Spaulding Rehabilitation Hospital to continue her recovery.{{cite news|title=Teresa Heinz Kerry Condition Improves: John Kerry's Wife Moves To Rehab Hospital|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/11/teresa-heinz-kerry-condition_n_3582496.html|publisher=The Huffington Post|accessdate=July 23, 2013|date=July 11, 2013}} Heinz was released on July 17, 2013 from [[Spaulding Rehabilitation Hospital]] in Boston. She recovered at home after some limited out-patient treatment.{{cite web|title=Teresa Heinz Kerry released from hospital|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/07/27/19719730-teresa-heinz-kerry-released-from-hospital?lite|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=July 27, 2013}} ==Philanthropy== Teresa Heinz is the chair of the [[Heinz Endowments]] and the Heinz Family Philanthropies, disbursing money to various social and environmental causes. She assists the City of Pittsburgh, where the Heinz family has many financial and family connections. In recognition of her philanthropy and activism, Heinz has received [[Honorary degree|honorary doctoral degrees]] from the following 12 institutions: * [[Bank Street College of Education]] * [[Beloit College]] * [[Carlow University]] * [[Carnegie Mellon University]] * [[Clark University]] * [[Drexel University]] * [[Kenyon College]] * [[Medical College of Pennsylvania]] * [[Pine Manor College]] * [[University of Massachusetts Boston]] * [[University of Massachusetts Dartmouth]] * [[Washington & Jefferson College]] * [[University of the Witwatersrand]], [[Johannesburg]] In 2003, Heinz was awarded the [[Albert Schweitzer Gold Medal for Humanitarianism]]. She has been elected a [[Fellow]] of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]]. She has been a Trustee of the [[St. Paul's School (Concord, New Hampshire)]], which Kerry attended. Heinz is on the Board of Selectors of [[Jefferson Awards for Public Service]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.jeffersonawards.org/board|title=The Jefferson Awards for Public Service|date=2009-01-06|access-date=2017-11-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106145805/http://www.jeffersonawards.org/board|archivedate=January 6, 2009|df=mdy-all}} ===Environmental programs and advocacy=== Heinz has contributed to the environmental movement through many programs and outreach efforts. In 1990, she co-founded the Alliance to End Childhood Lead Poisoning (later known as the Alliance for Healthy Homes, it has since merged with the [[National Center for Healthy Housing]]), through the first environmental grant of the Vira I. Heinz Endowment.[http://www.dep.state.pa.us/dep/DEPUTATE/polycomm/update/12-22-95/Vol1No47.htm The Title of the Web Page] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060306001326/http://www.dep.state.pa.us/dep/DEPUTATE/polycomm/update/12-22-95/Vol1No47.htm |date=March 6, 2006 }} In 1992, she was a Delegate to the [[Earth Summit]], representing Non-Governmental Organizations.{{cite web |url=http://www.johnkerry.com/about/teresa/ |title=John Kerry |publisher=John Kerry |accessdate=November 13, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080808135141/http://www.johnkerry.com/about/teresa/ |archivedate=August 8, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://icte.umsl.edu/docs/newsletter/vol10i.pdf|format=PDF|title=TERESA HEINZ TO RECEIVE WORLD ECOLOGY AWARD|website=Icte.umsl.edu|accessdate=2017-01-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070705092828/http://icte.umsl.edu/docs/newsletter/vol10i.pdf|archivedate=July 5, 2007|df=mdy-all}} In 1993, with Kerry and environmentalist academic Dr. [[Anthony Cortese]], she co-founded Second Nature, which brings "Education for Sustainability" to college campuses.[http://www.secondnature.org/aboutsn/aboutsn.htm Second Nature | About SN] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070209103932/http://www.secondnature.org/aboutsn/aboutsn.htm |date=February 9, 2007 }} In 1993, she founded the [[Heinz Award]]s, including a category for Outstanding Contributions to the Environment.{{cite web|url=http://www.heinzawards.net/ |title=The Heinz Awards |publisher=The Heinz Awards |accessdate=November 13, 2011}} In 1995, with a $20 million grant, the Heinz Endowments provided initial funding for The Heinz Center, "a nonprofit institution dedicated to improving the scientific and economic foundation for environmental policy through multisectoral collaboration among industry, government, academia, and environmental organizations."{{cite web |url=http://www.heinzctr.org/index.shtml |title=The Heinz Center – Home Page |publisher=Heinzctr.org |accessdate=November 13, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20080409142050/http%3A//www.heinzctr.org/index.shtml |archivedate=April 9, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} Since 1996, Heinz has hosted an annual "Women's Health and the Environment" conference series.{{cite web|url=http://www.heinzfamily.org/programs/womensconferences.html |title=Heinz Family Philanthropies – Women's Conferences |publisher=Heinzfamily.org |date=October 1, 2004 |accessdate=November 13, 2011}} She founded Teresa Heinz Scholars for Environmental Research, which annually awards eight $10,000 awards for doctoral dissertation support and eight $5,000 awards for Masters' thesis support for research having "public policy relevance that increases society's understanding of environmental concerns and proposed solutions."{{Cite web|url=http://www.hfp.heinz.org/programs/environmentalscholars.html|title=Heinz Family Philanthropies - Scholars for Environmental Research|date=2004-06-05|access-date=2017-11-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040605020512/http://www.hfp.heinz.org/programs/environmentalscholars.html|archivedate=June 5, 2004|df=mdy-all}} Heinz is a board member of the [[Environmental Defense Fund]].[http://www.environmentaldefense.org/aboutus.cfm?tagID=365 Board of Trustees – About Us – Environmental Defense] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061201234617/http://www.environmentaldefense.org/aboutus.cfm?tagID=365 |date=December 1, 2006 }} ===Women's economic security programs and advocacy=== In 1995, the book ''Pensions in Crisis: Why the system is failing America and how you can protect your future'' (later republished as ''The Pension Book'') was published, with support from the Teresa and H. John Heinz III Foundation, and a foreword by Heinz.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hfp.heinz.org/programs/womensretirement.html|title=Heinz Family Philanthropies - Women's Retirement Initiative|date=2003-12-19|access-date=2017-11-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031219200600/http://www.hfp.heinz.org/programs/womensretirement.html|archivedate=December 19, 2003|df=mdy-all}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.biblio.com/books/37833981.html|title=Pensions in Crisis: Why the system is failing America and how you can protect your future - Karen and Blackwell, Kate Ferguson|date=2007-09-26|access-date=2017-11-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926222803/http://www.biblio.com/books/37833981.html|archivedate=September 26, 2007|df=mdy-all}} Spurred by the issues uncovered by ''Pensions in Crisis'', Heinz and her foundation created the Women's Retirement Initiative to "extend that investigation and examine how the dynamics of our pension and retirement system contribute to the disproportionate rate of poverty among older women." In 1996, the Heinz Foundations created WISER, the Women's Institute for a Secure Retirement.{{cite web|url=http://www.heinzfamily.org/issues/womensecosec_02.html |title=Heinz Family Philanthropies – WISER |publisher=Heinzfamily.org |accessdate=November 13, 2011}} ==Wealth== Heinz and Kerry signed a prenuptial agreement and have kept their premarital assets separate{{Citation needed|date=February 2017}}. Heinz has declined to disclose her personal tax returns, citing family trusts and privacy.{{Citation needed|date=February 2017}} She is estimated to be worth between $750 million and $1.2 billion.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/jun/27/nation/na-heinz27|title=Estimate of Heinz Fortune Doubled|last=Vartabedian|first=Ralph|date=2004-06-27|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-11-21|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}} According to her most recently released income tax of 2003, Kerry and Heinz paid an effective federal income tax rate of 12%{{Citation needed|date=February 2017}}. Heinz and Kerry live an affluent life. They own a six-floor, $7 million townhome in Boston's [[Beacon Hill, Boston|Beacon Hill]] neighborhood, an ocean-front home on [[Nantucket]] recently listed for sale at $25 million,{{cite web|last=Balling |first=Joshua |url=http://www.ack.net/Kerry-Heinzhouse060916.html |title=Kerry-Heinz house on market for $25 million - News - The Inquirer and Mirror - Nantucket, MA |website=Ack.net |date= |accessdate=2017-01-26}} a $5 million ski retreat in [[Idaho]], a $4 million estate in [[Fox Chapel, Pennsylvania]], near the Heinz family's home base of Pittsburgh, and a $5 million home in the [[Georgetown (Washington, D.C.)|Georgetown]] neighborhood of Washington, D.C.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} ==Politics== Like her first husband, Heinz was a registered [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] for most of her voting life, and she remained a registered Republican despite being married to Kerry. In January 2003, she changed her registration to the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]. In 2003, Heinz was named to the [[PoliticsPA]] list of "Pennsylvania's Most Politically Powerful Women".{{cite web| title =Pennsylvania's Most Politically Powerful Women| work = [[PoliticsPA]]| publisher = The Publius Group| year = 2001| url = http://www.politicspa.com/features/mostpoliticallypowerfulwomen.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040209095936/http://politicspa.com/features/mostpoliticallypowerfulwomen.htm|archivedate=February 9, 2004}} Heinz is said to have been encouraged to run for her first husband's vacant Senate seat after his death. Heinz declined and refused to endorse Republican Congressman [[Rick Santorum]]'s [[United States Senate election in Pennsylvania, 1994|1994 bid]] for the seat. She publicly denounced him as the "antithesis" of her late husband, and later called him "[[Forrest Gump (character)|Forrest Gump]] with attitude." It was rumored she would challenge Santorum in [[United States Senate election in Pennsylvania, 2006|2006]] (as a Democrat), but she did not enter the race, and the Democratic nomination went to [[Treasurer of Pennsylvania|State Treasurer]] [[Bob Casey, Jr.]], who went on to defeat Santorum. Heinz has a reputation in the media as a very direct personality.{{cite news | title = The Making of a Non-President | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A49993-2004Nov14.html | author = Kurtz, Howard |work=Washington Post | page = C01 | date = November 15, 2004 | accessdate = July 29, 2006 | authorlink = Howard Kurtz }}{{cite news | url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/6407226/site/newsweek | title = How Bush Did It |work=Newsweek | date = November 15, 2004 | accessdate = July 29, 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060619172718/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/6407226/site/newsweek |archivedate = June 19, 2006}} In an interview published in ''[[USA Today]]'' in July 2004, Heinz was asked about the differences between then-First Lady [[Laura Bush]] and herself:
"Well, you know, I don't know Laura Bush. But she seems to be calm, and she has a sparkle in her eye, which is good. But I don't know that she's ever had a real job—I mean, since she's been grown up. So her experience and her validation comes from important things, but different things. And I’m older, and my validation of what I do and what I believe and my experience is a little bit bigger–because I’m older, and I’ve had different experiences. And it’s not a criticism of her. It’s just, you know, what life is about. "{{cite news | title = The real running mates |work=USA Today | url = https://www.usatoday.com/news/politicselections/2004-10-19-teresa_x.htm | date = October 20, 2004 | accessdate = July 29, 2006 }}
Heinz retracted the statement later, saying she was "sincerely sorry" for the remark. "I had forgotten that Mrs. Bush had worked as a schoolteacher and librarian, and there couldn't be a more important job than teaching our children", Heinz said. "As someone who has been both a full time mom and full time in the workforce, I know we all have valuable experiences that shape who we are. I appreciate and honor Mrs. Bush's service to the country as first lady, and am sincerely sorry I had not remembered her important work in the past."{{cite news | url = http://www.cnn.com/2004/ALLPOLITICS/10/20/theresa.apologizes.laura | title = Heinz Kerry apologizes for remark | publisher = CNN | date = October 21, 2004 | accessdate = July 29, 2006 }} Bush brushed it off, saying, "It didn't matter to me. It didn't hurt my feelings. It was perfectly all right that she apologized. She didn't have to apologize. I know how tough it is. And actually I know those trick questions."{{cite news | publisher = CNN | url = http://www.cnn.com/2004/ALLPOLITICS/10/21/laura.teresa/ | title = Laura Bush brushes aside Heinz Kerry's remarks | date = October 21, 2004 | accessdate = July 29, 2006 }} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Portal|Pittsburgh|Boston}} {{commons category}} {{wikiquote|Teresa Heinz Kerry}} * [http://www.heinzawards.net/ The Heinz Awards] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080720091106/http://www.johnkerry.com/about/teresa JohnKerry.com – About Teresa] * [http://www.washtimes.com/national/20041022-120846-3334r.htm Polite society anticipates Teresa's pizazz] – from the [[Washington Times]] * [http://www.heinz.org/ The Heinz Endowments] (the Howard Heinz Endowment and the Vira I. Heinz Endowment) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080828171728/http://www.visitsunvalley.com/thismomentonearth/ Visitsunvalley.com – This Moment On Earth] * {{C-SPAN|teresakerry}} {{John Kerry}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Heinz, Teresa}} [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American philanthropists]] [[Category:American Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Colonial people in Mozambique]] [[Category:Forbes family]] [[Category:Heinz family]] [[Category:John Kerry]] [[Category:Dudley–Winthrop family]] [[Category:Kerry family]] [[Category:People from Maputo]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Pittsburgh]] [[Category:Portuguese businesspeople]] [[Category:Portuguese expatriates in Mozambique]] [[Category:Portuguese emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Portuguese philanthropists]] [[Category:Portuguese people of British descent]] [[Category:Spouses of Massachusetts politicians]] [[Category:Spouses of members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:Spouses of Pennsylvania politicians]] [[Category:Spouses of United States Senators]] [[Category:Spouses of United States Cabinet members]] [[Category:United Nations interpreters]] [[Category:University of the Witwatersrand alumni]] [[Category:University of Geneva alumni]] [[Category:Carnegie Mellon University trustees]] [[Category:Pennsylvania Republicans]] [[Category:Pennsylvania Democrats]] [[Category:Portuguese women in business]] [[Category:People from Fox Chapel, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:People with acquired American citizenship]] [[Category:Breast cancer survivors]] [[Category:Catholics from Pennsylvania]] [[Category:American officials of the United Nations]]

revision.text:
The '''Texas Enterprise Fund''' is a business incentive fund that was created by legislation in 2003. The fund, which had an initial $295 million investment, is used for ensuring the growth of business in [[Texas]]. One of Texas’ most competitive recruitment tools, these funds are used primarily to attract new business to the state or assist with the substantial expansion of an existing business as part of a competitive recruitment situation. Sources indicate that since 2003 the Fund has yielded up to $6.3 billion in capital investment in Texas by out-of-state companies [https://web.archive.org/web/20081123123323/http://www.offthekuff.com/mt/archives/004974.html].
In 2004, authorization was given for the fund to grant $20 million to [[Countrywide Financial]] in return for a promise "to create 7,500 new jobs in the state by 2010." The grant (all of which are approved by the Governor, the Lieutenant Governor and Speaker of the House) is one of the largest made from the fund in terms of the size and the number of jobs promised. In the fall of 2007, while slashing jobs and with its stock price plummeting, Countrywide was eventually acquired in a [[fire sale]] by [[Bank of America]]. But thanks to the "claw-back" provisions in the program, grantees return all funds to the state for jobs not created.
In 2012, it was announced that [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] would be adding a new campus in Austin, creating 3,600 new jobs. The Fund would be investing $21 million over ten years.[http://governor.state.tx.us/news/press-release/17021/]
==See also== * [[Economy of Texas]] * [[Texas Emerging Technology Fund]]
==External links== *[http://www.texaswideopenforbusiness.com/ State of Texas economic development]

[https://web.archive.org/web/20080530045149/http://econ.worldbank.org/external/default/main?menuPK=1697684&pagePK=64168176&piPK=64168140&theSitePK=1697658 Trade Costs & Facilitation: The Development Dimension] is an ongoing research project on trade facilitation reform carried out by the Development Economics Research Group of the [[World Bank]].
The project is focused on expanding knowledge about the relationships between trade costs and private sector growth and export competitiveness in developing countries. A major focus is on exploring the dynamic gains associated with lowering trade transactions costs and identifying the relative importance (net benefits) of related reform measures. The project has two primary parts: research and policy relevant analysis, and support for new data.<ref>http://econ.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/EXTDEC/EXTRESEARCH/EXTPROGRAMS/EXTTRADERESEARCH/EXTTRADECOSTANDFACILITATION/0,,menuPK:1697684~pagePK:64168176~piPK:64168140~theSitePK:1697658,00.html</ref>{{Dead link|date=December 2018}}
The project analyzes trade facilitation effects in a broad sense, as its analysis spans the entire realm of a typical international trade transaction; this includes, among other topics, the transparency and professionalism of customs and regulatory environments, the efficiency of supply chain-related infrastructure, the harmonization of product standards, and conformance to international or regional regulations.<ref>http://econ.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/EXTDEC/EXTRESEARCH/EXTPROGRAMS/EXTTRADERESEARCH/EXTTRADECOSTANDFACILITATION/0,,contentMDK:20696563~menuPK:1743267~pagePK:64168182~piPK:64168060~theSitePK:1697658,00.html</ref>{{Dead link|date=December 2018}}
== Leadership & Funding ==
The Project is led by Lead Economist [[John S. Wilson (economist)|John S. Wilson]] of the World Bank, and is funded through a Trust Fund at the World Bank established by the [http://www.dfid.gov.uk/ United Kingdom Department for International Development] and a [http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/TOPICS/TRADE/0,,contentMDK:21712530~menuPK:4850719~pagePK:210058~piPK:210062~theSitePK:239071,00.html Multi-donor Trust Fund for Trade and Development].
== Research ==
[http://econ.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/EXTDEC/EXTRESEARCH/EXTPROGRAMS/EXTTRADERESEARCH/EXTTRADECOSTANDFACILITATION/0,,contentMDK:20714814~menuPK:1877579~pagePK:64168182~piPK:64168060~theSitePK:1697658,00.html Research] associated with the project has included policy working papers, presentations, learning events, and research briefs.

Wilson (economist)|John S. Wilson]], Ben Shepherd, Matthais Helble; World Bank Policy Research Working Paper 4401. The World Bank. 2007. *[http://www-wds.worldbank.org/external/default/WDSContentServer/IW3P/IB/2007/11/14/000158349_20071114140515/Rendered/PDF/wps4400.pdf “Help or Hindrance? The Impact of Harmonized Standards on African Exports,”] [[John S. Wilson (economist)|John S. Wilson]], Ben Shepherd, Withhold Czubala; World Bank Policy Research Working Paper 4400. The World Bank. 2007. *[http://www-wds.worldbank.org/external/default/WDSContentServer/IW3P/IB/2007/09/25/000158349_20070925144522/Rendered/PDF/WPS4368.pdf “Trade Costs, Barriers to Entry, and Export Diversification in Developing Countries,”] Ben Shepherd, Allen Dennis; World Bank Policy Research Working Paper 4368. The World Bank. 2007. *[http://www-wds.worldbank.org/external/default/WDSContentServer/IW3P/IB/2007/08/28/000158349_20070828101307/Rendered/PDF/wps4335.pdf,” Landlockedness, Infrastructure and Trade: New Estimates for Central Asian Countries,”] Christopher Grigoriou; World Bank Policy Research Working Paper 4335. The World Bank. 2007. *[http://econ.worldbank.org/external/default/main?pagePK=64165259&theSitePK=469382&piPK=64165421&menuPK=64166093&entityID=000016406_20060721143416 “Implementing a WTO Agreement on Trade Facilitation: What Makes Sense?”] [[John S. The World Bank. 2006. *[http://econ.worldbank.org/external/default/main?pagePK=64165259&theSitePK=469382&piPK=64165421&menuPK=64166093&entityID=000016406_20060622151914 “Moving Forward Faster: Trade Facilitation Reform and Mexican Competitiveness,”] [[John S. Wilson (economist)|John S. Wilson]], Isidro Soloaga, Alejandro Mejia; World Bank Policy Research Working Paper 3953. The World Bank. 2006. *[http://econ.worldbank.org/external/default/main?pagePK=64165259&theSitePK=469382&piPK=64165421&menuPK=64166093&entityID=000016406_20060419160621 “The Data Chase: What's out there on Trade Costs and Nontariff Barriers?”] [[John S. Wilson (economist)|John S. Wilson]], Shweta Bagai; World Bank Policy Research Working Paper 3899. The World Bank. 2006. *[http://econ.worldbank.org/external/default/main?pagePK=64165259&theSitePK=469382&piPK=64165421&menuPK=64166093&entityID=000016406_20060118152026 “Do Standards Matter for Export Success?”] [[John S. Wilson (economist)|John S. Wilson]], Maggie Xiaoyang Chen, Tsunehiro Otsuki; World Bank Policy Research Working Paper 3809. The World Bank. 2006. *[http://econ.worldbank.org/external/default/main?pagePK=64165259&theSitePK=469382&piPK=64165421&menuPK=64166093&entityID=000090341_20050515133900 “The Cost of Compliance with Product Standards for Firms in Developing Countries: An Econometric Study,”] [[John S. The World Bank. 2005. *[http://econ.worldbank.org/external/default/main?pagePK=64165259&theSitePK=469382&piPK=64165421&menuPK=64166093&entityID=000094946_01012305305688 “Quantifying the impact of technical barriers to trade: A Framework for Analysis,”] [[John S. Wilson (economist)|John S. Wilson]], Tsunehiro Otsuki, Keith E. Maskus; World Bank Policy Research Working Paper 2512. The World Bank. 2000.

'''Youth Business China''' ({{zh|c=中国青年创业国际计划}}), abbreviated '''YBC''', is a [[non-profit]] program in the [[People's Republic of China]] that aims to promote youth [[entrepreneurship]]. It is headquartered in [[Beijing]].
==History==
YBC was initiated by the [[All-China Youth Federation]] (ACYF), the [[Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security of the People's Republic of China|Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security]], the [[All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce]], and other agencies in November 2003; YBC is implemented by the [[China Youth & Children Foundation for Social Education]].
By using the tried model from Youth Business International and marshalling resources from all [[social sector]]s of China, especially the business community, YBC provides business [[mentoring]], [[seed money]], skills training and network support to young entrepreneurs, thus helps them succeed in business [[Startup company|start-up]]s.
YBC helps young people aged between 18 - 35 who are unemployed, under-employed and have a viable business idea and the passion for entrepreneurship but who lack business experience and have no access to seed money.
YBC provides young entrepreneurs with between US$4,000 to US$6,600 seed money; one to one accompanied mentoring; knowledge and know-how in running a business and access to business networks
As a non-profit programme with a [[think-tank]] function, YBC has been pursuing its goal to "promote entrepreneurship, enhance employability, create job opportunities, revitalise the economy, implement social responsibility and promote social harmony". YBC inspires the potential of youth and encourages them to take action.
In 2005, YBC was accredited as the best practice program by the [[UN Secretary General]]'s [[Youth Employment Network]] Office China.
==Cooperation== In September 2008, [[Hewlett-Packard|HP China]] established a Chinese center for [[microenterprise]] development in cooperation with YBC, providing support and training to microenterprises and enterprise starters to use technology to build and grow their business. It provides accessory training rooms serving surplus rural workers, social youths, college students and migrant workers. The HP Microenterprise Development Program, which was introduced to China in 2007, is a nonprofit community investment program.
==Working team== YBC National Office Working Team *Gu Liping - Director General of YBC *Yang Huadong - Executive Director of China *Zhang Huiling - Executive Director of China *Chen Hao - Director of YBC National Office *Cui Zhiru - Project Manager of YBC *Zou Shujun - Project Officer of YBC
